However, only one-third of those showrooming consumers actually act on it and purchase items online..." (visit AdExchanger)
*	Media And Creative Collide At ANA Conference <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC2Rzio1uDMN26UANa3ayI9g0rmBx5rzDGE9e0gYtfkJZZr4EULda3bdRYL1XKW0NA5YioGiN4b7xZaOixvkty25InSX5bXvgC5iMk33IMdxMApw_mKuWHxwnPFXL3cBf5B05zwnal0tBxMhjfJQ4N0TFjwdAvfEHwAalr86L-8VglAah5xGWxr2CTw4cQZWGDQ=>  "Realistically, unbundling won't be reversed anytime soon. *	What Makes Premium... Premium? <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC0XMHau2ObpReS_VG71cLzi1BIglij2YFEhUJG6GSek5Aei9n1_qEY7n9tyjOWG4eyZ1UkvZrYmW0R84_3WSMDFOKgB2wz732xosWpk9ixrw1tT1ZjrIgcYXCFsrZO4ePkhmW34pIq72EMtDCnqbHr->  

*	Shawn Riegsecker, CEO, Centro: "First-Party Data Attachment: inventory with proprietary first-party publisher audience data associated to it separates it from inventory utilizing aggregated, and mostly commoditized, third-party data." 
*	John Ramey, CEO, isocket: "eople doing business directly with each other, where transactions are not auction driven in the spot market (RTB, private exchange, etc.)." 
*	Lorne Brown, CEO, Operative: "Premium inventory is creative, it's innovative, it gives a brand something they can't get anywhere else... and because of this, it's complex." 
*	Jonathon Shaevitz, CEO, Legolas Media: "Certainty of inventory, pricing, delivery, and placement of ads." 
*	Roy Pereira, CEO, Shiny Ads: "The inventory needs to be a prominently placed ad unit that offers a first look impression for specific criteria, which the publisher guarantees for optimum placements during a specific campaign." 
*	Joe Pych, CEO, NextMark: "Is adjacent to quality editorial, advertising, and other content - in a 'neighborhood' that builds brand equity."  
*	Joelle Frijters, CEO and Co-Founder, Improve Digital: "Provides the right context - Context counts!..." (visit AdExchanger)

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC3bQYqoe53IPyqRSyeTDzBnSFk4hl10LsoKeAOt0p91y5Tq44QpFS_95ud5QbnJfVx3nmukIv-ge4YKFYwlHBkTdpwaWz7Fjh5_WQhKs31Ev9XNlh43Mpts2VRdtYOML2c=> .

 

AOL's Ad.com Gets 'Friended'


As AOL Networks head Ned Brody plans to refine the company's supply side offerings, its demand side, third party ad network is likely to see a boost now that it has access to inventory from the Facebook Exchange. As Brody writes in AOL blog post, "We know that advertisers want to include Facebook inventory in their buys - we're seeing it on RFPs - so we're glad to be able to further meet their needs." Considering the challenge AOL's owned and operated sites -- along with every other digital publisher -- is facing from Facebook's increasing dominance of display, the depth of FBX's inventory is something the ad ops side can't ignore. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC3kWj_Yr3-GFhNdWz-Dmeo4uy1Dzxc8k6ks1rUgiULP5SV61k2pwZNhl-86ZHoPWWSWPRNdBiOGzu5Mc_bvfV1y8YvTcoZY7Md36Ur7p_Dc1JaB4tx7YpRUG3tZ5t0gthMpjPfc8nJLqNDHwkc7YqHaPZAV9UqzAb4cvsvMKOLqVdIMbULtync96CgyJ1r2Ooe_adqFnt4k8P9_cN0lJCSl> . 


Sharethrough Adds Digital Vet Keane


It's safe to say that no one has nailed the "native" ad format down. Sharethrough, though, bills itself as a native ad specialist and the hiring of Patrick Keane, the former CEO of content aggregator Associated Content (acquired by Yahoo in 2010 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC1cYyLylRAGEwzTBSdWngMF-tYYiQ4pTf1Jz0jPCMrguP3D2V6auaIZPjVV5T8q3Gk93P7sxy1QpR4pryJFbBQdzoRxyW_ynZs3qreomi8R4K6HraiW1biohGUWVB0NqFX6MK3R7XywmxlcFz-mAvS4NELkOScrBSk=> ), as its new president, suggests that the startup is ready to branch out, says AllThingsD's Peter Kafka. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC2Iz97RjqwLfEXm6G33aF3I1VWnRpCYF9SOFErx-iy0hSg57ViCdLg3kAqPAwxFMECt3EVfEQarHOhnOm2uZ3Ylse32tAYnBcAcRKXMD3llxp3h9sM3FUvMef0HpbBLBfRxPsX7KGGE2CNbXYxEQyBxaSpsQW55IZNYOaFCSWeJ9O3PkzBvpHopUt1FJ64mQqj0XXJ7cYoafG3Wng05Wwuh> . This past week, Sharethrough began working with Land Rover as it rolled out "sponsored stories," which is designed to showcase and distribute all kinds branded content, including text and infographics, not just video. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC0Yen4y5wq9p3Ra0fp_jz9ZR3f-KZopMtHVigz6fGCHSdK4mvVC7izqWj-Gg7lhNcmlQaosm9xzdVZ3BJC11d3UOA4hTA4nSmZ6IZ4DuSLxscM64b2EKOFwD92D9Mcs78JP2xy4UXiV4HkdvtcMq3KsiqpmtPu3Mbh9qWHlGhsv79cKfiflwwqo4GzxUfQbgrnwdtnhrgU2NWx9SSm3zSUfapYLXOOy6DI=> . 


Digilant, Consultant


With a new consulting practice, independent media trader Digilant (formerly Adnetik) wants to capture brand interest in programmatic. There's no retargeting talk in the press release. Rather it's all about "creative that works effectively through targeting and measurement." The company works with some big brands and agencies, including Pepsico, Wal-Mart, Initiative and Carat. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC1ggse6s2HlBVew1nIyOyz-o46oSCjc00zk2eV25TInoRV4ZMQGOoXLS7N5PpGyDBHLW2djXMLli9gQU1lW_Eepkvr4waaghDcMlCKQmo65XnNAcwqnygLbbXdeQGdEL8iD7jKj19rQ7SCRxmg4bKqbSoGp_kSAHGCGVyGiqQTDP14C1rx-oO-OapX137syIrZpAFoOS3OUFzoQEcnJVFDIjeHpowI8FrNg6nin9jlimh9TchPDF2mGAKhoqLz9_KC3eY--neOjuw==> 


Mad (Ave) VC


In one of its periodic pieces on agencies-as-startup-investors, AdAge notes IPG has a $200 million annual line-item for M&A and investments. The small part allocated to "investments" is divided further into agency versus tech/vendor spending. "We're not a mutual fund," CEO Michael Roth. "We need to structure deals whereby we can strategically use it for our clients." More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC3xWYLE9GJSZdQP4KC3TAFTELBoGln2mghhqRioKga9pQv0GtchJCY4D6qD0oVDEIjSSHRtLanO_KvtJGNjfh57Oodf1vPLAN29F7Piua5Ehw91JQPbzqxGYcAF8E-MfXuaQHkbvbbjtUSwlV7Uf8gwbjpwgcNLpXpSudjIpJWUnF34S0-ANBRJ60CMfBQkDWE=> 


Euro Video


AdMonsters and Adap.tv have released a new report on European video advertising. Among the insights from the Euro survey: "European publishers also find themselves in a quandary - while they're increasing supply of inventory to keep up with ramping demand and seeing extremely high fill rates, 54% report CPMs have stayed the same year over year, with 13% actually seeing decreased CPMs." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC3lraluuOKPEyXO4jXBSRp408oxLvbYis7CkPHBHcWaXYDHuWwRn2or41veb7RAP8H5EQqaD20eOjU1HWqWh4CLTTIaNOrvPFrsnesVUA1FGvROmd0Bnut_HevvLKHiNmD5TBj5lc_5JIAB_YOagcA3kxX-6BUE83xg_mlFWLCxqTN5A9LhEe0C3QxJ5D8sOjo=> . Ad trade The Drum chimes in with a review of the data, too <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC06cosTYzxVYqQfiH0bFp1lTYBq2fSqCHIIFSQMczpjk6p_uHReI4sBNz-Md135ufYMlNEVJUTOq519Vvbgms68YnfGQIuCJCK1TsHiyNQLYWiSeF3HO144QExOFI4FtbARaKq7Fh6Sd-mBkjGwt0CBhictAYo0PXBbN7qvIG8aoGrCtwEr_IdyVCTZKtGl1pgaqUn4G4H7twHhxD7pXbsrL3WaEGrzzAM=> .

Dialing Up DOOH


WPP is making the connection between billboards and smartphone ads by building out a full-service, out-of-home shop in its Tenth Avenue division, which includes DOOH ad network in Spafax, reports Street Fight's Steven Jacobs. The point is to look beyond QR codes, which have largely failed to make the connection with mainstream consumers. "As technology develops, and interactive signs become part of the landscape, these technologies are going to create an opportunity for consumers to interact with a campaign, and allow for a more performance-driven model," says Spafax EVP Patrick Bonomo. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Fv7j8bwxiC2_3DLsxc8WQmPhpypwscmRFKNdv9QwnFbUXsCgKi4la8CgsSkYNpWP2eTkE4OIgT3pUO1ssgfWN0YmfF44KVFIfTBxOeCVGiIDuAGXTNr8VhjddQpehR4pOQ-CL7NaqsU5gBy3vpVcA2IRxEaPgA6vdlQCCbDr-tpD0rkqic68GlVsb44PiDR04fcFOIfGW_y7hbzOa2xQQWoz4FshYjh9eL2EKwnUg5Q=> .

Google's Addressable Email


On the Google Developer blog, the company announced its setting up Google+ single sign-on for apps which dovetails with unifying its privacy policy <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1qLg2ADEh6SolggkyMAmK2m_tMeZ3TVDFoM5_Lkc24wTuNBuFjz0EWKbKLSzGRLqD521RQk1rSTSZ19QX5z9znA8D-X6yb64K4VhLMLUhE7OzoLFUwYssTqKA7BrQpuIY3MjyykGkvi1kGIouN1G5krw13G67mXMlEOuKfI9pUPzNnT9lgl6GHi7sJckdTWA20=>  across Google products and services. From the blog, "If you sign in to Gmail, YouTube or any other Google service, you can now use your existing credentials to sign in to apps outside of Google. Just review the Google+ permissions screen (outlining the data you're sharing with the app, and the people who can see your activity)." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1pYq1Y9lAtWGAwhaocsCZrNUfm4LUgAQK6WsSG8gDdV7rRs6E_Nxvbmlv5FIJwRF4R6hMFuaPucyTIUYrgfFZonHtMHEQVvfEfOx0fnKvS87zAVsrjBWSogLO6SZnNsz9uoE6N6KmMouXjDtCKaO2gAoY_9iQjVyun8fpUfLCUg0w==>  Cross-channel addressability gets closer for the GOOG marketing "stack." 


Now Rebranding


After having acquired european ad buying services firm Mexad in January 2012 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1oDiJ4wTgJuBuLrmCBWdJhEaclVg3LTEOUIUYA_cbs_y1Z0szClvgGrO08ZPYhdrntGyIqMMXQEHWNmFAI6AcTMZXof6SupU9U7qK5Kh_pB7VwPabi3A_SnlDXJrg1sOhmVZSuvx_tNMx9GigEEo2mJgjTyQmB_RJnCqspKUqbYIbejELxQKbtO5uUENiwJcS0ZBkY-lPpNMXjIk_JkXTpZeDJ4nhqUfa9_Q9Lm9EjkXg==> , ad buying platform DataXu is drawing the "DataXu" mantle over the company as the word "mexad" goes into the trophy case in a rebranding move. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1q4T31wK1qCLo33l6Zyat6-0kZjrvnNBSEkrkCcK4t9iinbaWOxEWW-KHWfN8eTBt7dh1K34nYIbgTpEnjb6KelKnDEpw28t56jm2po8f8-DnNG3k2zR_ZBSzOFY7ADN9RrFV-zvY_MJbOc_um5k2Jo>  According to the release, the company formerly-known-as Mexad <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1qk73tPYcFIB2orVsP_fApqsFXeL-lNHgYM0LAr4lqx6i8K0owDZIZnmQFnrpYttmACPud7eQt34IDkT3cfbO4get0sJRcvGGMLfSQrXiYUCrVWP-GieFNb>  is bringing DataXu's demand-side platform Kool-aid "to 11 offices and operations in eight countries." 


CCI Rider


Ad exchange and publisher ad server OpenX may have spawned a new way of announcing funding. Last month's $22.5 million round included Samsung as you may recall <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1pEuDLHn8MPOHDuqXWRq0XdytCXOkWNkcu9eJaPwKnLajdsn18TuK3QGJ_biuALFm-aFBLAw256VYLutZbdvRXyMaUQeqsR4zJNmXaTMyFLhZEu12CeC55thaV5qoxY_Zx3zFswusAJYKUKNwke2tRuwpE4qB6fzOZ_GKl2waMPT8z3xrCSpurcQjFituxrk24xKuFSQIPrk17x9eSwAoc8lXlRuIP9vvuaQ6YKijkRiw==> . This month, it's announcing an owner of another segment of the investment - Dentsu's busy Cyber Communications Inc. investment arm which is placing bets all over the ad tech ecosystem. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1ouWaTWr12Iht-gmCWlsZPesAj_dtXNPkW3cFAf5_4YUudJgjd7rMqeTxP20MGAuk9U4lbMskWbhhNARtieLp_QhS6wyI-CkxUUcExV3_eZwaDm81eD5an2k_g00u8EiyGnCb_s7KrJri_bTO5woOONfGNC5vmkRQqJxcWfGXf23-ToUQ2vF9Ej2wtmfIjjmINIztxYsQ-GUPXMafiOZMlJHZcdrs8NN0lcyEjw6mssLQ==> . CCI has also invested in Maxifier (see it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1rQrF2ucZUASze4okma-Th38o9ote9hX4-9PPjtDBQI8yGezu3aYZnOFS9Ahcj0OyKbZ0VvixkTMsPQ8Vt7XeIU-aT7kE0HtPBwd96cqgFl7jAgiU6MvQJygyv-JyseCk-h7RiqcQ5pzeMkJLzLwpQtQTbGRo4wsArkyAaidNFE3A==> ) and Jumptap (see that one <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1qvgqhbn1wvvqHz-jcu3k0xP8vY87KFOiijFHEV0vcLmNJxY9jnEPas7jNSfyi30u1mIcSSvtP2d57HBaBDhkuKyxoE2kodUL2-a2YBOrAG5ZZP4Gx79ce1JxKCUMNi4WqvUkuQPysTN29u6Fc0pK1T> ) and struck a strategic alliance with buying platform Rocket Fuel (read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1oPICa3aANVCU9hiG2zzInPKVIFoXC99C_a6aI1DPplbNxlN7zUALCptc_7FzaeiofQrgBNLjg1Y0KAaH8syo-3dh0z8VdFGThx942hdphhCdiSPV3khsXPK40wkIVftDG0N-6h9ctwlL0Mz_jaVXoxMVzXsTiH69Sy-pS93QqN2AVbp3Cxq6a2pAxWK6UC_meMz4L4hPF7PNa5xVFWZM5K> ). 


Strategic Engagement


Facebook "Strategic PMD <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1o7J5iYDNerCiiuNNr6eEdD-adzFQKrC6S6cqd1BYx8UGFS2arEe6S5pHHTrACYjLKu4bjLGBk70qnuqBCR-wWBF_lKvLyImTvK5rR5VJ_e_9gxSxky5gG4SQp7rnDETBy3p0ghQeJ543P0JqjnrNDlNKUMJDst--uzYsjy9rc0ew==> " SocialCode, which is owned by Washington Post, is breaking down the attributes of a Facebook action (likes, comments, shares, fan reach, reach, viral impressions, virality, etc.) and productizing it into "Message Optics" - engagement analytics for clients' Facebook fan pages. The release explains that Message Optics, "reports on the organic and viral performance of page posts to inform decisions about posting strategy and paid media." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1pA7CcxUm55CcWU02Qw9dYRSAArZZx4h-KwNYgY6RS5pkqRm2CRSoRGxCGaW0VCB42T6H31SLxZhW5xkYitqcxH1z4zRsL5tQMkGGCcgI2JNZ4IA1JC36Dbed03M-j-cq2qIFb8y_A1U6uwU5OHNFLl> . 


Seeing Mobile


A new report from Nielsen says that consumers kinda like mobile ads, and others kinda don't. Findings for you: "About half of smartphone users in Brazil, China and the U.S. said they were OK with mobile ads if they allow them to access content for free." Get the report (Pay with some PII). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1oR8Njei1Y4ns3OmijqIua4avibr5HWmLGWosvpDDddbvVQUBo8hBta6a4os2NWbu6wprzwBqcgLdSC3oySxHzJ_oGjKKQNDOtxsoKa9d59hxkyuLFLEvh27YI3zCe8TK1PqDFyA0AIDINTmQ2VbBZAM2i-njyLBc8nNl79nOHDPMRorA8NkwqgbFVNRYY3rupHpFKhHL3ATZPWm-W1vHQkCt8W8CQObUOpbhtnAoLunApAwEaJCTMQsT1PVCNVVWs=>  Or check out some nice-looking global, mobile audience graphics on the Nielsen Wire blog here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1rHx_cmh_ShOlOWPE0OA2fFrI-y9FQ3nEWMYt7w-Lr_WitMmlfIZVFfnzaCcbDSOBuCLedM50cEFnIvIPUTBapMTeT5FLkqBB615_uSK91pdTAyNugLRlufzzotZBDytw-EXKMzGQIbseZFsRKVMKJv0Feqkb2rSUj30wbXGizVRmywiXbmEQ7djZij7BGDWBBN-sbb3MtDcQ==> . Apparently, Korean users say they see ads in mobile the most.

Showrooming It


Research firm Ipsos MediaCT teamed up with the IAB on a new "showrooming" (visual here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1pX1YuV6cHie4MAPJsfGGUAIIXDjeyTqtAv3nXyiJTg5raxSP1cFCPPI6LmXv6z9vzQUznD6KvLWBg9_R2Wjo4jKOlWSJfPbndrEMyRZuihiO2iwnkQMze7Ef_DFdtASsgBQraenQnnTYuKwm5pUWD77fsJ-uh19pw=> ) study which identifies how e-commerce is impacting brick-and-mortar retailers. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1qsabaP5DxLTf2yg5Zq45UrY3pcoa5al3GX_EonzyIYJ6OYYm7ghX3vrkBCj-X1EQk74tUj_Bk9ySBTmtlV-4qSk24RAgKWuvPPZHBA8YJ-rLDM6C9ZH_Rj> . And, get the study (PDF). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1qv06-V48-idRlS4jqRyG_72Y6A-uanCfJfC7TkgVh_Uvrj57wXxZndyk0g62GkiwG3Rox6zgpsby84BL98jkpGD_xnwU64B_iL_Tg0IPNVN7_7kBt_NZideHswYMu9q60y4S1BET4ox9XMubOxIr70S4PzM2u13SDEzbTsGj1zPZGW3rZ0D6E2GEgWYjZp_wo=>  A finding: "The mobile component of the research was that while 42 percent of in-store mobile device using shoppers ultimately made their purchase online, a full 30 percent made their purchase in the store." 


The Secret IPO


Vertical publisher and ad tech company Glam Media has secretly filed for an Initial Public Offering (IPO) says Business Insider. BI's Owen Thomas says the secretiveness is a function of the new Jumpstart Our Business Startups (JOBS) Act and a lotta companies are doin' it. He adds that the act "permits companies with less than $1 billion in annual revenues to start private discussions with the Securities and Exchange Commission before announcing to the world that they're going public." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1oR_yqDY4IwNYwJ0CI7i25oKkndzQ6eIQYZn9JZZTZ4X3hgOHHKMdGw9AW1O7fvcTi1MbOmcBkX7XpCDuhZzStEPdZ6sZM6RNKbIhv3QVpcoZvLCnOV-8q80YtbvnGrdf5szPjORlKCnhS-hJqMT8O0LySYjA0NHLw=> 


Fantasy Smart Ads


Yahoo!'s 2010 acquisition <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1qezKnZJNafj3cNrvYhmlo2NQTWdl65XA7d2O3kAWxfRdavG6ES5z0zwHCk5neEwJfAqeVk-8RKfrFXcKSo7eFSJZ6KLusBXugJkxomoYuAO54oAyyEjNGyYXnYtPUUlEwf4A2rGjc5WA==>  of demand-side platform/dynamic creative optimization (DSP/DCO!) firm Dapper is still cooking. The Yahoo! Ad blog says as much and identifies a use case for Yahoo's Smart Ads product - which originally used Dapper tech <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001twgHf-NtH1q5FOzEDr0nNQDpES4aJFtsZqQadT-XxdeVJR4-WGKWTAiDT6hVy1-toowV2x2R9y19rdJr4iKaidnIXJKenXgBoR2Wz7lpiVIaX8Gb4FXREbrgBLHl4XpCofNWkGF0Uefrxz6mcirFZvbQL03bIGMlRanns-HCwqI=>  - that was shown at Yahoo's Fantasy Football Partner Summit (no, really). Survival Of The Fittest


The Internet Advertising Bureau has unveiled its answer to the famous (some say notorious) LUMA Partners' ecosystem map <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUst3rvlGMoC3wpxDQw1Yjmsj-ZxMW1rJanQ5xDyfUwPcNTyJfTI6btjFMMYpD-5O6hcQEufdBwI6hvIfBIf-BxOHla71hQ1jNI5bhcAsNSujTnjsJTJxsTW-cdOcbETWYchAG_1--cCeZn5kvBXZwq8Dq-QjtHCeGbE=> . In the IAB's version, the brand is at the center. See it now! <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUsuFRkGnvppvPERlPZoVzUIBV0Pw7hP3XjnoKHB6bd0s7VPvZ-T2r2B-bR1ZBFdihZjI83zMsmBufW53tTFDMnQamT-gwojSXA9wfKNyxl0CfQ==>  Why? IAB CEO Randall Rothenberg said at his association's annual leadership meeting, "Our very survival as an industry depends on us being able to help marketers build strong brands." Read the tweet. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUssajbSRsvNJmrHel68bEENeJDs_DU6VmILAFuGn8mThU0BcjP2FAtvayzMf_XH18jwFh0AXpw-sTvJBzbWKH_1R9VUSUb5eMd8zcPj5KT3qCMwzprRjIETnkiWNglORt5BF7pyO4Uwumg==> 


Yield Biz Dev


Adobe's data management platform AudienceManager (was  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUssqzjpfqM1bSJXmwSxMx74bv2KOtgyaJmHtFyesl5--e5jT_7ZAo3E7ReUnhmYVUO57cPGYtGJ3XOpwACG7L5AU9S_2YAZ7yyeDpbqAU2g0uevks5CDz0gHPk9fjweHnCWI4l7HywumpC7cLKwJ2ieL5z7QwGFvI05Qh32pel5VPg==> "Demdex," acquired in 2011) will now link up with yield analysis tech firm Yieldex so that publishers can "build targeted audience segments and identify site content where advertisers can best reach those segments." Scripps Networks Interactive is the first customer. Yieldex is an interesting fit for Adobe and its (formerly known as) Omniture group. Future acquisition for Adobe? Will Google step in first? Or how about Yahoo from "downtown" (as Marv Albert would say) as it looks to build its sell-side story? Anyway, biz dev release - get it here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUss7ZciY9RAwlrYH18xNJPBFzQoVAEy0bCAtPrjXn9G50JM5EdHszK9-qNN9K_vnfbQSZktBW2s0xgvM619c7PBIBBmeGGkO7yf4DGB-qo4gsTZoYo5PtrN5gN74lbXPKuU1cf3VM8mn73QISrUu3GeCAznxxkulC7vuJDRJ-3lVSITQMHCQlwB87JCG5f5OtdlTndbJN5MCh3SyAMQgb8b2Mbg-fFvEUQiPT7zdWY3Zc0rAwzVikIECkf9yaHuKHReG46jObCmw5s-zLyMVEy6E> . And, read the Adobe blog <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUsuo0vnQXZ0GhPs09JwMNMoQYds0xCYscYSGtCWnZr78p_Xh9FDxdWewZa519A0mc2ZkYE3HYyaeXVHUOoQz3gxStsClSvTYNv-QOzLX2lFIt-1VwtPn44x9N4rWGZMMnqncT1IEE64lmBQoBT88GAuSo7Oh14TAMAntpehY9tzl91ebnQ53wzzaBpdEdyFsuwtE8mMjh2ahNBfN0G_2mMgfIOIfuPcr6D45DVlJZ53iap9HIBGip7cswo7nfJf-CwsiZXc_W6wK8CD6jDHczUY0qqj2hRZxmYi5dd_x3zrytw==> . 


That Purchase Data


Ed McLaughlin, chief emerging payments officer (CEPO!) for MasterCard, tells CNET that a new MasterCard payment is on the way. Goodbye greenback, hello MasterPass system. CNET's Roger Cheng writes that the system "addresses not only mobile payments, but also all forms of digital transactions. MasterPass is designed for purchases made in stores, online, or on the phone." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUsuLARRlN1oOQJT7TIJNtEI4l9V7paVgyYKm15MHKXWx3s3FyoipgjLk3exnEASEDTMDDts1d4Ww967_aO1gY--Vhz7R7RGvJCRee6IAKHmrHw3pl4nNoL1ZtYcPpvex85obs2Nd2CStsxw_GDjueKi91OIeVxDmN5Tso0PIejLlkVPT547PzZWY7NRFS79d4yf9yJymKqG6PbG4C6ofUh62> . Can you say attribution machine? Many of the credit card companies will have something like this eventually. And the loyalty programs will proliferate in order to keep consumers on their respective credit cards platforms, which will help cross the divide between advertiser and consumer privacy interests for online behavioral advertising. Here endeth the lesson. WAA wah. 


The Fox


Ruminating from the Internet Advertising Bureau's Annual Leadership Meeting, Upstream Group's Doug Weaver is contemplating hedgehogs and a fox. He taps the inkwell from his company's blog, "Today's hedgehogs chase the huge breakthrough about the use of data in marketing. But what if all the really big ideas have already been ideated? What if now it's about making a hundred great incremental calls about how you handle, interpret, analyze and act on that data?" Where is the fox? <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUstgCeiHF5NslPrsVsQJvQ9IqN4UEZ7tpMG4x345a4J0c14ha08iPwm5WM5jaUuQX0uAEdjqt7Hi1y7SIwGmyol_Vo4uOJs_AJm_TZq4GthJHnQOMGM3Myby_3sZc-pWBfqW9fIxsYqDdQ==> 


Less Is More


P&G is shifting to "fewer, bigger ideas" that can move around the globe. BizJournals.com reports, "P&G previously had as many as eight different Pampers diapers messages on the air throughout the world. It's brought that down to two, focused on a single benefit - keeping the baby dry for a good night's sleep." Fewer creative executions could also serve a programmatic mindset. More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUsttoMrE61q_Yxd6X-LNOo-6Z3QL5SjjWCEXNXJWwohBm9gdDbB5AwVJ-f-Iq2JwUgPNDy0zBvSRs4hPDbNJdF3z5omd80uihYrVIEGpCJJBT05ge5KshSbp__nZvNUk6_HjYRgxRnif6vLXtUu2olv7VEJGxnik1h82umxEieSL9lr3wRAZq3nPIZMJa7j3GLGVOOuvrCqqHwK5Am_bdHHv>

Facebook Budget


A new Ad Age survey says marketers love Facebook even more than they ever did as 61% are spending with Facebook versus 55% seven months earlier. Ad Age's Michael Learmonth writes, "We also found a slightly higher percentage that said their Facebook ad budget would 'modestly' or 'significantly' increase, 58%, compared with 56% in our earlier survey." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUstfnLwljyvDJ0k9qmK1TBQZMTBcsD8K9FXO-BND2PI2i2QDulQntUq1JRqjAf5m8dXgf_6Bk_Yp2kJDoiMl-yJjuU8X8D6zC6QDztARS-MoF_gi8oXj4uGbvAReuh7uGjMZEi1gQoRouRsfgWxE9tcGybyQ1IOnpDQD6VTB2H6lEAvmfXlN36eFSNp2Cb1Yf8y0-oQflEN1xDOyXsiYOg9z4M30kxHUIQg=> 


Infographic Tuesday


Mojiva shared some growth stats for its tablet-only ad network, called Mojiva Tab. Total ad requests grew 17% from October (3.6 billion) to December (4.2 billion). iPad is dominant with 59% of ad requests, distantly followed by #2 Amazon Kindle, with 8%. Infographic. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001nOjuzCaWUsv7KyrrMZI6X8QphThI95bOJhp1ISvVzfYFzm4K0G5odVKs6bRn73YIcU-w5DlA80qJwa335RBAQ4MdbjHeqxn0PHLgn6T4rmabx5fF4MnOwV6Z5IaSmBDDrxIhTo4tTyueO5IJEb7I5lAZVKmlF8yG5OeO5_C0GoGvGm9dWsH6qCVLXyiPUVN3>

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktQrlUSTY_USdbnuY1M_Wf3eomNFBPiRsb3Mkg1LiIFVvp4hcEFn2Hq7Ccn9dWzn5bczXof1-AC92CUoxuFE1_Cg9uQ4uViWGNqpn1QSADK6FVer_t_5UR-dt2aoA6ukIUI=> .

 

Addressing Loyalty


Facebook's Custom Audiences <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktR_bIabx-paR1EAtXqAu1JgoXT3PUqbBjKg-PEuGy53iMFhV0D8OSxi0cV1eqSmNd4qke6ioD1lTsnnlzyqqj5Sb7lrnZopsDtWMoAZVtCywBzbxGb38GROabFScCrowl7jAvynlBclUQ==>  product is being adopted by Epsilon and Acxiom in addition to the previously announced Datalogix says Ad Age's Cotton Delo. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktSnBBFEUrl71_prGuf6ovI1qkrrUHqRqQtRC1OMkkgiDnhqVE2WPDj_ikUZGr47DavGRBIwURDj3uSwid738ZP0Oewc1j5yL-70LorT908yuB215pKwDNvRZCushsbyvkQ6Ro0H_RjyLBdrE9bIzvzWQlACSn6xBjoT664zIt2vFS0uoa5V8RBy9A3O-Y5RkwuIMkBRFdVb8FFRSmgHhO8Ui_9h6eyZ7BA=> . How it works: consumers become addressable via ads on Facebook by matching a Facebook login email to email addresses in an Acxiom client's loyalty marketing program, for example. OMD's Colin Sutton says, "Our CPG clients can begin to micro-target specific sets of consumers based on their in-store activity and buying behaviors and customize the messaging." The bigger theme is those CPG clients who are involved - and it's creating a nice "hook" for agencies looking to sell-up. Many Ecommerce marketers have already adopted Custom Audiences. Programmatic marketing is just starting to take off. Privacy concerns remain a trip wire.


Google's Groupon Killer?


Groupon-like daily deals program is on the way from Google and dubbed Offer Extensions <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktR8rkpnh94K8y8OZWOUY5DQEB445pH5YXp1I6nNtE1wfRhCk1Dc3xhrTbdS50tECL3Ic_-JWoEDGd34yLNdd7qQAuVSgzOhaJ_J4x-n335To3MOJCu3MbIUCTNJt8T5e0C5RWT7ynYFE5skw4lkgYRKEYk-6l_lvUc=> . It pairs ads in search result pages with special discounts and is expected by the end of February says VentureBeat. Larry Kim of search marketing firm WordStream claims it's "a way better deal than Groupon, who requires 50-90 percent discounted pricing, then takes 50 percent of that for themselves. Also, advertisers can track this. Local businesses can connect the dots between online marketing and in-store purchases ... not possible before!" Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktQebhwBjT78aRk4rylFEk92AymxVLPqP91kyEWxIzNgyQgx1VktKicUTRZIyEWOuclYP436yl3nwoA_BC1ZsbdTti7jcctbuR0FbXVdGZTAcGnkVa8__DVEUoT8z87Cap2IjDzwPyecRhueENWAopZ6ZuzASNSMUxPT8mcZL1hUMJLMqzMf4HGqeONO8GtdMRcS3iJT2SFPj3N0eaDA-oD-IN3sw8Sc_uKWhGM0x2VFt1VLRxYVb4Gs5b6kjHxjMVNUpUhBveHGyw==> . 


Gambling Gold Mine


Online gambling is on its way to getting approved in New Jersey and Nevada in the U.S. Read more on the NY Times Bits blog <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktR6RZZ49ShmxkG_tFrGnUMLYGjJkD75d2MiHkjvfK_3fbpc9_3YMX5PMjyYXvXZQUZJk3G5Hs0UYJ42O5FfYM6mCZVeLf3c5C08_w4q9QkgNfOdQY25g11pWA7ZWDVNbNtiNab43EOY1gcH4IHQp12hM6Nthzy1-o9r4bmoVNo3-g==> . Those are extremely valuable users - gamblers - and will revive in the U.S. a money-making cottage industry around advertising to gambling audience. Exchanges and inventory sold on a per impression basis were made for this. 


More Money, Please


It seems data management platform/"media intelligence platform" Aggregate Knowledge wanted more funding after all. In a November interview with AdExchanger, CEO David Jakubowski said <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktR-4AwnmW49n2bQGv6LgP5u_nLC74ZYnO6P4buRKnf5OwxR11eA8e5-MtxzBqyj2qf9yAf2IbazdRzkQdf_YAbwoSRSW4VZ-TpVXDp3piXbbNcAiM_o0tFlr65_voahIUru-xk54sYc0MdfWOIbPJDdr5FrqUddEg4=>  funding wasn't necessary for its current product line but... maybe that would change. Indeed it has as the company scooped up $11.4 million in a fifth round round of financing (Crunchbase <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktRgzs3LHETkJW58cr8j8esy-bunS5ERCrbwK_iAuitL1lPwXrz_pLqirTGsNTrPTUnyt_IXGJHTggqWqbxIkTAw0zti1z74iP7hk4CLMMIL1MIoSaEoAeiQKkYSg4TDcajVmZxI40AacdNylhmDLgue> ). SEC link <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktS_rmWOQ2EHWhQWiPaaJUo1CICF-CIlKDg6fvRRUj_deFCKtmvvmkfA8SmzX6qoRaGOabVZWUJ8lrhNdQF7UAFbQNMmYHHYZYbAFl6Lo-33U0dw2eFxBxP95xoIWB1AVDccWo3w2G9DpRGW7IcagRGN6-1KXiNNwvFNdXobOguxW5cH58XC2pfhxo5dMNdf066IcpVspG4wvqtGnzKpnvqx> . A bit more in Silicon Valley Business Journal <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktTscP58a8NaArAD4p7k5SQajVfZ5rBW2wPaJ_3TlMusvhlDMk7PVVkAscGen6SZV4sHvguqklROhzGHd7jJWWiTxbq-h4l-M6bMd5FeTEnOwdG9--KrMWRmfVyGZgr1D2wWDpn6Tl8w6IZs7FngDt-kXtBSx_w4NEx26WrQ-2UPJca2zYQhBaJD88F6r1dI1AOi1sy8ZVKUtA==> . The new funds likely helped with the company's acqui-hire of Quantivo <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktSxVilYYfuiipE07UJHI0UyKB2OBcLDxH6GwnB4yuFABLIsxmKSmFX2xA3-T9Lcy0aSRo6PQBQl6S6zG-lBEaPkfckzSdeqHIj25BMLU17hk09t1JH5Acag5IrT306-716Oy1zvVm-HlQnUCM-9yjlOu6A_RS-6O8T1oe3X3otQUWjvUQfKITP3DpELaHJKyy1YKxtbycAc7hzF8J5k41LB>  earlier this month. 


Licensing The Exchange


Ad network Altitude Digital says it's now offering a private exchange to allow video advertisers a chance to cherry pick an audience they want at, most likely, a higher price. Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktT4f-3PHPKln8Q8tmddyZXTZqcyp455ofaQL6TN4yFCAadQxZQMbilIO12PSp8HEaGL3SKePQT8sHvX7gsJkuGj56odCFdMMEjPfSYRSPiUJTY6DavH-T0ghzQn5cdmL3KCey8iHE1LPi9VCq5NGPGlo0rtPM0L0h6n5PkBh0eIm7HeLWzfRY7W6u5kWWeEnMzayiC1i9sCHF5gptzoJMV4b9wvW-WCVQFm3Kj6QdjkFg==>  Adap.tv will "power" the private exchange with its technology.

Pleasure Card


Digiday's Jack Marshall looks into the rate card across a number of well-known publishers and finds big numbers. But, one anonymous ad buyer tells Marshall, "Rate cards are a bit of a sham in digital. No one pays the going rate for anything, and sellers try to make every agency believe they have the lowest rate, and that they're the smartest, most strategic and a pleasure to work with." Read about it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001JymulTd5ktRBGVOz2FD_ralnYYxcNhyElZDKJi8X2wCxfNGyJf9wZu2TdzPYHUQq45ty_TL4fWyEC7duva2Z7suN_1d15xFog7Xtfvz2g_FBwx-9-o2nsvr66dEP-Oudm90AylENAW-C0OO_t8xtXIc2YMsYc879JW-c2CUjYnc=>

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmAQ3bt8uG30B1srq_aNimxHETsc3wnmAduPvfDBbwOqObRB94fWrGR_zZDMxat4IjaPkkNmzrvb-ITZa8AIhqjJNxhhV6X036-VUrN_MVOk7QQXWXf8Y8d7inpdILZCRa_0=> .

 

Automating Twitter


Twitter's new API program opens a new front in the "fight between humans and algorithms," Mathew Ingram writes in a long riff on PaidContent. "In a nutshell, the API is a way for companies to automate more of their ad spending. At the moment, the list of official partners isn't that long, but it will presumably grow - and the API combined with Twitter's self-serve ad platform will theoretically allow advertisers to promote tweets based on what is trending and where the activity is." Next up: cookie matching? More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmAR66uphyMMyQCeVfBUMViz7v2kkEoa3BxEM56dW_8FTQt9DERTp2gY3XqR6WwhfwQJ9BPPi-mZ6ScyVViTTj6gEcI8zQXIFR76Lh6Zv7G87pL2PJW5RFhgrzP55wc2tCUMFufeCw6rg7gW1nMHaVbLsytUJdcull5_LxQcMCGNzCyzh8BIiPoJrfmbvEXHW5uFfNW94OThuD_DYsQH890NbZloUiX8m_nUIxPTYaNzD0w==> 


Rising Stars Stuck On Horizon


The high-impact Rising Stars ad formats trumpeted last year by the Interactive Advertising Bureau still suffer from an awareness hurdle, Undertone finds in a survey. "Under a third (31%) of marketers have heard of the Rising Stars, compared to over two thirds (69%) of agencies." Meanwhile cost and production hurdles are still a barrier to publisher adoption. On the bright side, among buyers who know of the ads, 73% are "very or somewhat likely" to buy them this year. DSPs and trading desks are still not big users of the formats -- which include Billboard, Portrait, Pushdown, Filmstrip, Sidekick and Slider. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmATXdFRY4OtchYw3RYId8ysDuzIBwXvL1hWvnb9t6GQPgHFksAFHgZEhSvijLFxPWdopd-nv3wQM8TfD29z_p3ZhpPucuYUIIStyHf0cwRPZvSiwkjgfigASs21L82zO12bFnU22x62cqlXJ5nvh_R1G> 


First Party First


First party data platform Adara has scrounged up $20 milllion round led by QuestMark Ventures, which specializes in expansion stage funding. The company uses transactional and loyalty program data to execute display media programs on behalf of clients in travel, retail and financial services. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmASac94XR9QG0bDhVweCsTn197b-sh0Z5PG2SDy82t0m27ajcOvdz1JlUBnpdA0E3dpfrFACulmNhcHHnPcgz5MuvU8t_5Da3uFLpbI-ArP3D8w3hAoZjYM_xK85Xp1-qKjaFe4HuaWvcHweQ_iJh4vz2vfl6_yKcq6EmMGp9qCarOGobyC3dffNnH4c717K4CALgqPbiD1Snv-tmGsr0wcU52wciwHicSQ=>  And, read this 2011 AdExchanger interview  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmARu7Av5V8nT0hcZutaYi8A7SA0P0VO6qby8zCbnItlrkjSsAPskSEGXq-4etmmhLYfd8YpMEOOmb4N8LqpKQC1P9qVkgKAMPdHZYU4juzfC6p12w0vkg06O6Xee82pMc_jflYvNqw_9XuXGEKpIwmhQHzM9ICMm9WDKO_dSL8ITG131lcTL21AROibH3RNRQqGuXrhR3VZCyG8xK4VeYwuZMlMItiuPoHlKuvlaz6jT5jBluOfKGkFHYN132-R_E9M=> with CEO Layton Han for more background. 


AdRoll's FBX Warning


Although retargeting specialist AdRoll was an early Facebook Exchange partner and clams to have have run FBX campaigns for more than 700 advertisers, the data it's releasing today is based on 468 campaigns from the past six months that ran simultaneously on Facebook and the web suggest that it's not a happy participant. Among its findings, AdRoll says clickthrough rates were 40.18 percent lower on Facebook than on the general web, and Facebook Exchange ads also had an 86 percent higher cost per unique. "There were some things that we expected, like the lower CPM and CPC on FBX, but other things were surprising," said President Adam Berke in an interview with Techcrunch's Anthony Ha. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmARRfWkdcSb1WQeuKvXm4D887o7bqiTJ8K_l9R2JV9-U6MmAJXubICEgnSmrJt2A5NTLQpxG6IyURmc8QnnC9QKCaLOFuv17vQ8beEByn2dj0p1wxMzWiE0LXQNvxa6sfifdxsA9lT538W-5vIflzjfJQGOMm64iSy8=> . 


RTB Hot Buttons


Gus Spathis, search retargeter Magnetic's CTO, lays out some of the burning issues that industry executives have been debating across the conference circuit. Writing in Mediapost, he points to debate over the value of "place" or "content and context" within RTB. "If you are reaching the right audience at an optimal time, does inventory matter? Does media placement make much of a difference in RTB -- or is it just the data?" Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmATn7DCz_mYxb5o-G9RhPAoHsVVx9m0wgc46FYimo2RJNKSbhW4v5yK950Ze3qA9rtUFmiIHpk39e4NldFBj-SEZzu9-WtQsGfyVVAsijZXCkOT2OucO5lwRrxnUc0IHTVJrsUFDOzfgSUKL1KkyR_oLYH5sWEsRw0_Gy58vm-Bf2XZU4Jut3PSaymciJBkfd1Z43m1DVZF-9a-Rs64qsqOw4pe9hdyG6OPRZS2YA3EmAw==> .

Where Accrediting Is Due...


With companies like Integral Ad Science (formerly AdSafe) having moved from after-the-fact ad "verification" to "predictive analysis," established companies in the verification business need to do more to prove their value. DoubleVerify reports that it has received accreditation from the Media Rating Council for its suite of Verification and Viewability products, the latter being a hot topic for marketers these days. "Achieving MRC accreditation confirms that the innovative solutions that DoubleVerify has pioneered over the years to drive online media transparency and accountability are proven effective," said Wayne Gattinella, CEO and President of DoubleVerify, in a release. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmATJgCXhw3nWZ41cXq17jXvmpXZlePxvvA4W3i_oWUqiMKRll5SQwVD3n-gpuhJoF4XiWt0Ep9-k-E0HvgucdsSC_W7RVRg4DZhh4VW9FSLLIpTKqy8BsWLiuBr4IHWlcOAnqvJ7lJ0ed4g-bwHn4YGkr-Qn4HrWFAbhxpIve0qzHpwLfpMnbTT3fGABy5jsqA8=> . 


Private Co. Earnings


Attitudinal targeter Resonate Networks, which has made "hay" ($$$) with its targeting capabilities on behalf of political candidates, announced that it is seeing bigger and better revenues year-over-year. In the release, the revenue mix is described the thusly: "New business: Brand business outpaced the politics and advocacy business (116 percent to 107 percent)." Read it all. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmASJjan_Z3f2CJOQRapy8zzbRBgCy5he4ndu9vxksUwQGfVpcj2sJIxYGJHKCy_D8hXKFkPTWFT7qRk6mlnKFd8hqP-7vL0oN8UeIy2jYN9UPT77z-SQRt7KQWqltNU-Www6iMRbHYIWS1S9Xy0YdMzWsHDXIDqEW8IgHa6KjkGNuNuvy_XfoFPO6HI9UvzTwSO2jmsvOFJ0BF0_Vl4ZqmE8T3x_0WfpLnK6CTh8zXk8dmRiuUSgtGs_iYR5HXSn0Bk=>  The company raised $22 million a year ago (All Things D, 2012 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001wZoHpNYXmASqJxpCfbJY7MhEEJtgrKSAAlhMH-BOu218x2BAq9hdtq3pdGJwNXqTCjSJjRekotG7Ui4O71lbD7CPJpWfdQRpPxt6zL5_3Rm04BDsCH_tQ4XoCYYNVpEYBotj5BW7Dr0yvVBeDpFgNcepT1CfxFSpCxQpbxafnUqnlaQ8gAeS2g==> ).

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?

Chasing The Revenue


Millennial Media's Q4 revenue leaped an initially impressive 68%, but compared to previous quarter's 88% surge, investors and observers are feeling a little disappointed at the growth prospects for the mobile ad network now that it appears to be facing stronger competition. Chief Executive Paul Palmieri pinned the revenue stall on a decision to avoid business that pays out regardless of whether consumers end up using an app, which he described as a short term strategy for competitors: "Ultimately, the receiver of that download, of that incremental download, isn't really getting anything. This is fool's gold, and there are a few companies that are pursuing this strategy, mostly smaller companies." Read the earnings transcript <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yML30CmC97RcGZ6MvXdm5qCvwuCzMC8-g4sSv2ItISZVS4Pe3pKiAF0c0G8HUgzE_HFJ1EPpUsumYexPl9e87GfeZwq6TcquW7htmsQIiFoosvLotghIQjBhHt2AKOJlAJ1MhNn1rfDdMuasp0IK7eKUihKXqp8RMj5ccN6wnQJuYwBCn1otoXed7xkxmSyaGejtMSBUr121qitOsOIWCq3CDwJByX7feJ_kI5bMJ_o2GSMWooZ3pDnS>  from Seeking Alpha for details. In the meantime, Millennial made it official and put out a press release regarding its acquisition of mobile media buying and RTB targeting platform Metaresolver. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMLRq0jfV9eSCLVTDdje_2xwVnBa4SqVyR1PlR1jLEVrOL0BeDgJalBOo42QXObwDe9_E_T0v9AuYMFziNavH2zmf5pKGQGP5Nvhy0u2w37966imF1YU-TOjSYbZubshlK7e--RXkYgSk4N67vgSckCGUM7min3q6BCcHx5fVPt2N1PvNCQg9YUUwb3tM-Iegaw=> . 


Global Viewability


Matt Drury, head of interaction for global solutions at MEC Singapore, tells Campaign Asia-Pacific that viewability of ads can differ by region. He says, "The size of the problem varies from market to market, but it's usually worse where digital is less developed and there are fewer guidelines on publishing." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMITLEmUlBNk1e1Q-S-dupw30h6iEoS26yCuWEA--qMwyMNI_CoIPIZpFa23QSvQZdsihyUhhIxWLNLLmruTj9RtYjeUJPwcI6MLOF5lYLL_SzRzZXF2TXF9KbIy16klPcYjpYGG0AfTpzA71fYUxRipKz5ChzyYyuTHfJYI10Fw68UaXM3xb1Lif8Y42o_UU_TjI4sQjmi5oCz46D4BMj5W> . Viewability goes global. 


A Newish Yahoo


Portals may be considered dinosaurs to media industry professionals in the age of Facebook and Twitter, but millions of people still visit Yahoo and AOL every month. But the amount of people and the time their spending has indeed been shrinking and the hope of turning that around has been slim to none. Still, give it up to Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer, who has written a blog post touting the "new Yahoo" aimed at mobile and tablet users and the advertisers who covet them. Apart from that, Mayer was short on specifics: "Over the coming months, we'll continue to make changes and improvements, so today is just the beginning." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMIJksXZ780XE-TNmPCxa-uJGe7A1ph4nQdZbUB9RSKSSJnl1kTeeURm3tfUY-udvjbVpWEPLjJiVFD5vxnpx3Ie1idbpJSB9XpcB_SBW70IPLGnzE0WlFumpTGFFpyErYd-7XvCrX9CrsVX593fuF03J6riRKYyZDw=> . 


Programmatic's 'Premium' Problem


Talk of "programmatic premium" is getting louder these days, but it's not necessarily becoming clearer. At least for publishers, says Undertone co-founder Eric Franchi in a series of blog posts. Writing on Digiday, he says, "The reality is that advertisers want to target audiences, optimize for performance, ensure viewability rates, pause campaigns and shift budgets to different channels for many reasons that don't reveal themselves until a campaign goes live. To date, the champions of programmatic guaranteed have failed to address this fundamental issue, which, at the end of the day, leaves publishers with little progress toward their end goals of higher revenue and CPMs." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMI4xFhBJ-Y4vi_y19kl8TYFETbtrdyMbPaSSsH0hF7RBENcVDP89zQeJSQZbPnborUmaybDUMi7tNU5wp-u3JQdlhEraz1Jrd41Gp5RccQe5ZoTKFavSOxeD0lDndfqejsB-I3Ev2BS7ZrLgGysfiPvkAJtje6Afl6a1ehMi1zmlB1K4MmZyfMj> . Elsewhere, on his own blog, he suggests thinking "about time (and units of time) as a native digital concept." Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMLh8erMQUeo68h4M5b3hgvv5U8ZDlwlkXTUijApZRPdBNeJ5yNWVXMfz1FNcO3RlLKUE65Y6xbPYIQDMyLOrJT9Hqf-MctrjEJISkjmIvXDsRwPQ6ZYLyK-fZnwH42DiJ0y6sm3GrzbtMEDgw9k1_LH6GlzZXouYH2ser_6uN3ud11t8ky_YvUs> . 


Mobile Ad Alignment


Sprint is partnering with Telefónica to create a mobile advertising alliance intended to reach more than 370 million mobile customers across the United States, Europe and Latin America with targeted advertising. The effort is centered on Telefónica Digital, the interactive arm of Telefónica, and Sprint's Pinsight Media+. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMKJUeGPv-y0GDEgrluHkxbnRA2Sv4Zd_OHmDN8eONmk_bzhyfRVosDjaMWJxnwLgEdqh8ZIIqjnDNPDsHkTtiW7XSGp18ConTYYgajImN5uYVNie8IxANiFkCd_Cwp70SLbqEpjp-3FiQlnRn6YwDM2g3wkAI-yfMn1-2Ql1e73_TsoGDsnaiDHNWznYM-TzA3--aOilPKwPBlsmwIlutg_FrIZLXIu3d0WhQZadE2QNw==> . On that note, Rubicon Project's Jay Sears says there are seven steps to making mobile display successful. Read 'em. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMKQK9y-2Sd2SKaDUvM9U_glXjW0NxeKz4y18VK7TSGRQw7utovtvSv-phUfv1xLsyX84hMOnaZNoLaqpAUKuZrU7eoNs0DPmIIZLPDj79wFGok7vfK5igKDJ2rH3RNxi5mQL49qsZvNQt6wE-DJ0A3q7ijXUdJTeGP2SwDxlYFg-KRvGj0kqf6kxGwYbtQo3fU=>

Imagine More Data


DMPs and DSPs still leak data, writes Dax Hamman in a piece on Search Engine Land. Not only that, they "force buying decisions to be made on data that is out of date." The solution? Even more data, and better cross-referencing of datapoints. "Imagine as a marketer, being able to know when one of your customers is in a taxicab, and whether they opened your latest email before they got in it, whether they have bought from you recently and whether they are due to go on vacation soon." More.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMInckhmXGsnJXc8yexjvwc7Z4K_I8tgh8UO8uQwqD0-d6mUSOlJQbYdzc1LcXM1J4lWWCCsKd18uK3-a7pHNCVZ36BAIFOEQHlyoBO5LOqSlphB-JieITlJhMyOIFjX3TyYiLccEzmye6rgDZml00ODN1SRrQAuIEbguazSppspVwrr3RkPqmcAI3BZi5u46Mg=> 


Tracking Spend


On loyalty marketing news site Loyalty 360, Phillip Britt offers a profile of Caesar's Entertainment and how they're unlocking "big data." From the article: "The company has gone from being able to trace 58 percent of money spent with the company down to the customer level in 2004 to being able to trace 85 percent of the money spent today. That provides Caesars with unique insights into customer behavior." And then they can personalize messaging. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMLzLL6hrbSu44j67NC_eNADR5IW0z-mHcclVQ5WTjxx4UW_xb3l6U4ihpw-M7_ZHNTMcYsSlds7vYhWauJoWX4UCpF7QyOPZ_QFxsUomvrLs_HaNtnWpzxmC9ZrCNh1buK3IupquhE30C8HJ8dKxkhp51GrzGc41Cx-OiCmzeQguemMFDJNyghZ4e-aBiVWyGRwOfT5AWMgxC9suUt2Aiyp> . 


Reserve Price


The Right Media blog has been running full-tilt (relatively) lately. Yesterday's subject was setting a reserve price for the sale of display ad inventory. It's not so easy says the author: "Like many other disciplines, setting the optimal reserve prices at different levels is both an art and a science, so you shouldn't expect to have all of the nuances nailed right from the start." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001tvypbcF9yMIXzjkLDayzFWinRzgySQIYvv3OlZARzqpNw21zokaNH7TD_uTUPzNEafurClzqjcgsgJol6Xvyk-UY-G4i20Tk12xSQmevoU3I5IJTIHqkM5rDmbzHU9lb>  Art and science FTW.

  News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUw4_gv7gEuHCyF74Qfgr6-pZTCU2kQJYbF89tXa-IpYrqGScXu_v3keumQhBM5T9wuSHSxJnefjPvv0netdFoZDyrE6zMkMz3tHbtf1OeCthzbmOS-LxQ20boErgj9-ED4=> .

 

Adding UberTags


Digital marketing hub [x+1] has acquired tag manager UberTags as it looks to expand its data management platform capabilities. David Skinner, SVP of business and corporate development at [x+1], said UberTags represents a natural extension for [x+1]'s business: "The company's technology was hands down the strongest we saw. Their architecture is compatible with ours, because the tags can support data collection and outbound decisions... it was also the most intuitive system, which leads to faster implementations and higher ongoing client usage." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUxfXG5LZSMQ8w9mY6zNXt6Cj1u37Gmgoc2kHbZ8gFDhfuPiRTvofsaH3L8ob74BJDGPD3kOgfOg1GT4YDks4I1CJTm4fvml5zGk7phYjqlmjt_zyAVwfqemli2i4mzROgVOR8Zf1Z1NvWtD4uxbj_iL> . Mediapost's Laurie Sullivan has additional details <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUxKT8arS5qjabVF-NVW-CrSfsrZ3ASyw5G98LuIbsVq2_c_0yp9vE1YTW5_0ONP_4C2KRDWE8U8CM0sUjbs1JJECNLYywaqh-ZvLuFbOeu1Bg78arRt4UButjDnnIjCAvcN-16oJ9zYVwnIN3MYDkctUsN-QVz_F05Tc6SXq9Lm6cKm06CwmmdGLy2JEH8_AzdgwG-Y8wv7quJYLOZTWG4auwknCGF5Z45VMG39ZJD9Aw==> . 


Google Store


Looks like the corner store <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUyytodqmAU1rnyVbdfFrujTk68MC2wqxzHzdV8BZNpi-gaJ-gn-eyAPc76JkMrjHW8Mjamhrv3dTJH-06PL-Zzb7FUBIKt8phCXlWGN3kSg877PfiCMN7rx_qrGDNB0MhennlUu0_9wjTp1PP90zqqL3M1VtikJ5Jg=>  is of interest to Google. The Wall Street Journal smells plans for new, brick-and-mortar, retail stores for the GOOG. The WSJ's Amir Efrati writes, "Google could (...) use retail stores to show off Google TV software that is embedded in some TV sets and set-top boxes, allowing people to browse Web video content from their televisions." Read it (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUyeEuZqYftlxb1877knkdD2AOkgscsLYMXqXN0Il2rjQ72UzZTys8AHygtX4h5aIe0IgTYXMmxk2UfIZK_nbQ8HtmKJxehOT6YcAmlfSspK7H8HQuY1Da7vLewuONwrtKHChQYeUZIsK60_Our1qACGheMh8pRYPW2Hjr3poYpm48mKnUjN0erI> . Or, maybe this is all about data and Google could figure out an online-offline ad attribution system for a network of retailers? AdSense meet AdStore? 


Owned & Earned Need Paid


AllFacebook reports that agency We Are Social has added paid media to its reportoire owned and earned capabilities. The agency tells AllFacebook's Justin Lafferty "that this new service will help marketers deal with the convergence between owned, paid, and earned media on Facebook and other sites - such as when Facebook asks a brand to promote posts instead of just simply buying an ad." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUzm14sVRBX4etM_2KM28sR9499U8tXWS658z6pt08_JNwRcmdZ3Cm-kG7rKhAoAqDHrgduHuWjMnYIwL_MLEQ3Fn94CpdF4jl4VRKXptE3xD3G_jNN2No1AU49Sj_KcIVpEdjfOrO67LkLlIGmVcK6wk_vmDf-A6Ko=> 


Mo' Money


Recommendation company Taboola has raised another $15 million ($40 million all-time). TechCrunch Ryan Lawler reports, "With the new funding, Taboola CEO Adam Singolda says the company will double headcount, from about 70 to 150 by year's end. The company also plans to open new offices in strategic markets such as France and Australia. Taboola is also moving into an expanded New York City headquarters in the coming weeks." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUw-oT4CPDT0zvxLvl1Skx2DXSBHZGmH9CVCczz4ZRSwTdMFqQ8_XKMcVsW1Tcxd2x1Q1_22KN9NycqZQHq8YJm4-5G_jshM1Rn1oX4HSGuSKMUC5Kwf5Y1jwaQZelgDybLLz3Ct4Ui5bENu4PMdsXk3>  And, read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUw_H0h5EjfXK4Bf6kCTes_rUxtTqhSUdBoDLX5VjSNQsb9xw4up0zVlFREVFUfT7kvZzqdkSEnEM1kO5Egcc-BdFriaEtRcuI8AiveC_zuuURlcJnanYou3UF0W8ePltPTNtUjA4QzdDd58VNONcYooS9XMTiitaLX_A5QR1gEgmihu6367kT6HlmMFXodxeU52L0jXtqQ_5yfcECMKYNS3> . 


Atlas, Facebook Attribution Lever


Most people look at Facebook's interest in Atlas and see a future ad network. Bill Wise, writing in AllThingsD, sees an attribution play. "Facebook is less interested in using Atlas to port data out onto the Web, than it is in using Atlas to bring all those off-Facebook conversions back into the world of Facebook itself... Facebook wouldn't look to Atlas as the backbone of a new ad network; Facebook would look to Atlas as the infrastructure for tools that show how users engage with Facebook ads, and where Facebook fits in the conversion path." More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUyhgoIsd-_gRnM-yuP1BHgl6dJPyEDsFu1BFTKCoyAe9oro45NjpN80yyx57lBw7rDaqP7Pfdx1xPFGN4udsb38fQflc4Nvt3Y_rtnL6hJ8MgETC8Brdh9Qh0RM0xqgnY4CndW_IfOfGLMYpsuLhSWl0wCeqk7Z6-a86GAqQl9dEw==>

Sponsor Message

The DMP For Paid  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUybpSbmFOpvI4xIxRCgjfCWWJ_Bkj32qcYQPF4lGjYddqeqtKKS_jbYZY_wIlPwq1fR8u5YZzk6tXLtCm6WkSxmn-ePyM-yvQcVwmL2cuHhnaDrDS-JR_MiLQPOiuLxkn4=> & Owned Digital Channels 

Transform how you engage with customers and prospects <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUybpSbmFOpvI4xIxRCgjfCWWJ_Bkj32qcYQPF4lGjYddqeqtKKS_jbYZY_wIlPwq1fR8u5YZzk6tXLtCm6WkSxmn-ePyM-yvQcVwmL2cuHhnaDrDS-JR_MiLQPOiuLxkn4=> .

Agency Digital


Earnings season isn't quite over, and the other French ad holding company, Havas, found that although its total revenues grew, sales continued to slow down in 2012. Both digital and social media-related ad spending now comprise 26 percent of total revenues, too. David Jones, Havas CEO, said, "We continue to see good new business wins and growth of digital, supported by the unique co-location of our media, creative and digital teams. The year risks to be another challenging one, but these factors, along with promising activity in January 2013, give us confidence in Havas's ability to continue to perform." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUzDnMw6_do0uO2aKK7vsIxauDVCKM2_f6EJ6u2UHga_-CmGUO0xl_fz79VCWE30NdEPC3ojqKTngHuuhDzRmtxfuV48uFKDd0Z_a6mPzTVx_-RhW4ifEgnQjzDS_TCiwZMcomwTPduXMevKTyRPAlVDzw2EnLfXAq0=> . 


The Velocity Of Data


Business consultancy Accenture is telling businesses about the "three V's of data": variety, volume and velocity. Greater mobile usage and the mainstreaming of e-commerce are driving expectations for faster access to data and more insights from that data. "As data becomes more widely used and companies see increasing competitive advantage from faster 'data to insight,' the data and analytical skills in an organization also become more critical to converting insights to action before opportunities are lost," Accenture warns in its Technology Vision report. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUxhcab_1rZHcpTrf2DLDm-rVHVEnYB7Zd6vsH9Co0Hg2W6NIq1qjgSKyazoq3SLj6TFx3Uz8V5uRiFIeyWSefRWNIxzTA0JB4iELG_3Ste2AMls6vQz7F7Z7TSkbcrs3n05rJdqQbc-oM_tjF7QZF-J--dkZyJ_yI8DGF9x1oiWrTKsw7hCmVD8tx6knr35zsk=> . 


'Brilliant' FBX


Facebook Exchange still gives remarkably good ROI, at least in the UK. In a case study shared by Rocket Fuel, Carphone Warehouse saw Cost Per Order on FBX come in 41% lower than the average CPO across all other DR placements. A marketing exec calls results "brilliant." A little more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUzDOCcp8Ud1k17Dz-2pgEjZw5yYkEDAh6Nh8pf-frHax81hMa_gLN8GgexSVAmWvBJUcCPkOKFd0Zdk66rIsZoehYxmZ-XCiB2GHJw9BGLTfiJeXj5-EZVzs4jqrXUFnkzTQe74QXDYOFhcPx4-thgXTlSPP3UukwqZQXuT48q8ddEfeKTpsavD6gKI8fSJBlhd8a1ox7t_I3GbssxawQBdWR_l3-Lzw0U52RoxQLgfyg==> 


Mobile Purchasers


Buried in a post on 2013 trends, comScore notes e-commerce is migrating to mobile, generating new granules of intent data linked to handheld devices. "The first signs of mobile commerce affecting the digital commerce landscape are starting to emerge. In Q4 2012, comScore estimates that m-commerce transactions (from both smartphones and tablets) now represent approximately 11 percent of corresponding e-commerce spending." More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUxM2YD6Rjo9cWMELzJQvS9cWcVOC5KzYkLP6vZrk_6Xzb5V_6AFe0iRpfLR2WRTqu7q4uqFhQXCl-YQM3mm3Ryu5d_aeSkLaaCNCVq0LmIC8vj5CJs5Cy43jLwRvajjXb1r5faTicr9tsPGi7xRap6twv9vsa-r_widWH5F4CnzDD3kEtwmJI9_QxUEN-fKhWU=> 


NYT's Twitter Ad Target


The NYT has launched a new ad product that's designed to give advertisers the ability to target their ads based on whether a story is trending on Twitter, Mathew Ingram reports on paidcontent <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUwsEyOEvvpA8QbcM-bz6745XXjgTRGnHcCsyN_Ehn5uoKLSFRmZB_zFirY49OXDJLCTkab-K-v0yaKHpVedxVUNT-Y20YRCGFBAx3qSd3GCsnCq9o3xj7tOw2VeCcOnQEEC1I6KggD6aeSUviQoI-8dpamCaF1J6Y5uQfzda1SCyXpJs1F1o-wU_wGin7oOC9EYSKMvFLLkLYApJGGstE2QGObjUC_OnZs=>  (via Beet.tv <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUyneWpbMRSnqrItcJubM4ifQ5xZiF3bbMYxkGAweCaDQzSQx10mX8ZRkItBz23pcYW6uTX994yaG7NyHKHgyZXvratS-e_nO1Kf_n7kacdaIJX0CF3DzH_RhHU2bMR8LqwDXSj0TRpfWw==> ). In an interview at Beet.tv's data conference last week, Michael Zimbalist, who runs the NYT's research and development arm, discussed the new ad offering, dubbed "Sparking Stories" as the company's latest effort to connect its research on social-media analytics to advertising. In a sense, it's an evolution of what the NYT has been doing with other contextual and social ad tools like Cascade and Ricochet, which Zimbalist talked about with AdExchanger last year <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0014-WAqNMIUUyVQDZBekQM9-P1L0XKEx1zETRtqyB358C1JetBUUfhVfMdPqbnYOjevpYrZaA3lUzV3rp8e9YJhAQXEpp9fRIfZh_gcU91Ma1_Zan6q5se26cAAAhpptkYjMzljYaoqe9I7mUrUVvX1zeXO8Ac0H0fUmuBSYumpGhd3U00ML-qmsGkiIuc8-ntux-_84eKwiXy-89b7p0JGV1wtB-q7ZEhnOXSOBk1mJiysOEreOsprcJ1GRCZ-Gc0> .

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__ZcxaHnpiFnZtSsn16zOiMH1S-mYfsVCXjXFiP_KUhaPhc0cN-i4YPK4_eSE5nq2PDfCrZrX05HCI37cMtNphIsd4ypGAVHcfanR6GeCQ3pJW3fPyrA_q1UJrUZTbwelVM=> .

 

Your China Plan Is?


Mobile ad platform Flurry offers new data courtesy of its network that says China is the new king of smartphone and tablet devices. Seems like that means mobile ad inventory, too. Flurry's Peter Farago reports, "China and the U.S. had roughly the same active smart device installed base in January 2013, 222 million in the U.S. versus 221 million in China. We use a model to project the final February 2013 installed base for each country based on historical growth trends as well as the number detected devices per country through the first half of February. Flurry estimates that by the end of February 2013, China will have 246 million devices compared to 230 million in the U.S." Read the blog post. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__ZKPCU6cvtOgWcUTDFLrO8w5gKm9mKPIApKe__ec-roEA-QEc7vOdvpaEqgE4jFcXXEvyvdryafRLaXQ_Y7Rulo8940AtDUT4U4tzb0CB1hlcEh4b6OoUX4pTatKQYIAqlo1YaTm5FSM2FRiXf-Yjxhb3GwyTZFTLtF5Ugm4DTacv63BsFUzaa969c3ncks9VfCMHoDoR_B-Q==> 


Can Digital Viewability Beat TV?


Writing for MarketingLand, Magnetic CEO James Green tackles some less obvious aspects of the Viewability issue, including its potential domino effect on data standards and pricing. For those who complain other media aren't held to a similar standard, he has this to say: "Just because something is broken somewhere else doesn't mean it should be broken in the digital world. We have the ability to know exactly who has seen what ad and where, and while an error rate of 5-10% is probably acceptable, anything much beyond that is not." More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__Z4AgAQadSnOVg5ZEQ0jkNDtPfMmq22zR3z7NZBHJFmc2oN0BJMCN3bfdUQ0wCdXVEj0L5q6O6V0vdXsmlRyqfVlV1AHhytf9ObiF9uzS0Dnn7AkelMu9LP9Mg9n-F1bzSwZWWdTkbfTdoewCGbeH_1dZnjpeC5bbws9YxnSFynudd5k5rKlDgC> 


LinkedIn Is A Publisher


On Digiday, Josh Sternberg reviews the future of LinkedIn and why it is and will be a publishing powerhouse. He quotes LinkedIn editor Dan Roth who says his company is seeing "high engagement" with efforts such as LinkedIn Today. But, the company isn't taking success for granted as Sternberg fills in, "While LinkedIn can play a numbers game in the engagement arena - if there are 200 million users, even if only 1 percent are active, articles could get viewed 2 million times - Roth says that there's no such thing as guaranteed engagement." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__aF_xD7HwWvAxk2SZY5tLqsoQ23tMFnaGyPJ4l4exNf_lVv2K4alZ2BOaKI5IMZC5nM3EmUMPzknVBlsKhdTwM9M8ZImR0V9HeScSy-43IASgo7so3x_vji3GLgxwUHetOt_Dx5FXDdo1JK7NZNklvkepn75WESW5wi0oYsEBQHp_J6f9mWKxJK>  If you think a Facebook ad network is valuable, comparative CPM's for business decision makers via a LinkedIn ad network or private exchange should be even better. 


The Privacy Policy


Google's privacy policy is under review by EU regulators. Reuters Correspondent Claire Davenport writes, "European data watchdogs said (...) they plan to take action against Google by this summer for its privacy policy, which allows the search engine to pool user data from across all its services ranging from YouTube to Gmail." Ad addressability lurks in the data. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__bzAkR5ETNnoxvxxZLB5QxhkIQ3B1CXNV3j9O4cyAoDhr7weh1lV1sIbDDnySJltrnNNqPUHh1LXz5FMpkP6s4H2XBDDTLtSXVc7XacFdnrwulMENXCLjYqclOl-bEZKmghGhOvz3zTiv2b_Qn2FJeDrQRfVIAJ9MXwZTsjHb-dtCAdxg6KBV3yuch4rvxBF6M=>  


Programmatic Not-So-Premium


NextMark CRO Chris O'Hara asks on ClickZ, "So, is programmatic premium? Not the type of programmatic buying happening today." O'Hara notes the different layers of premium inventory within the "Premium Tiki <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__a06Tu_fTBm6zK0uKoZFbL2ZgYEJ_6phRxFlCgeon9JW3V2bZyLSxxkeKxzn-zhrm7cVAyLfFmlH3oydnjo0NQ2GfKB5OZqrOo35RNqjmKMulyoyy_SJRrD6JWES8MoIiA4CTmkCGGO7hJd7-oWEnOK0lzq1eVOT_4=> " and finds a lot lacking. Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__Z5cKtZPQhAQWQob0XjXRViOxNlnZXmVBrkcQmleGIr2sslQPrg48PotAGIzUFC1wn_UvuZ_rh0EleLcQiT7290_DtYIxiboIiput94YeKZXEabCROh-5ptuucNQuJtzFWJpGkZNpwmo2Aaqra9E6AqNpegj_NAH6XCRQ_7TDKtqg==>

Digitized Magazines


Former AdWeek editor and Vanity Fair bon vivant Michael Wolff takes a look at Time Inc. and the sale of its magazine operations in a piece on The Guardian. He concludes, "Curiously, it appears the faded jewels, so faded Meredith is said not to want them, will be left behind: <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__YDDB3aXtDfw3gXrqkwNtf2uqhtTLLIEHxne8MQZnVpI3Bhko7uCgxOfOKOvce-Ewswz3ssJtz4i3NEkn4w1SPBhmP55Hih7_oVDhJMu2ja2McZOvxaV6BSaJDirc2-uawR5PFnY67ctrkPmcY8HSKVE_p1CnhWDC1xuEzG7yqaJ88LrTvIX2eIHtuRi0FGjeA=>  Time, Sports Illustrated, Fortune. These are the greatest names in the magazine business and, rid of the dross surrounding them, and with a thorough house cleaning, a fine opportunity." Digital(-only) future? Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TGXUWCAw__a_A_sdHU0Ucc-iqhypweMXQfYL2WODBpJWCSzJaAWyudZ3eyL8Wa4tfsddBdB9LSyOAbcCYDqH-mcWxQd2Rl-05PbO9amUKCVGBUww51mDVfWATjxzKtiqZyO21l8tYwnib5GNU6h_UpWEEC3SOfZaMgbOI7GhppTrssUJck9LcAjvx_yIeHTatAcg6eR-V4A=>  Venture capital right this way....

Pirate Attack


We've been covering <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A8pXBr6udTs8gPHqdcjVNz_V7I2PLljkBaN3GaUBvROCBaIgbviiktzw55syqfdlzm2kzhO_lvXtZDAkIqVeaKvTaGrn8P2NaFJ_lEgC8JFP93iNKnS1IHpNPsuk5Wyu1p-C9QLjL7PW6wMzmsuN2hreAPJmu9Bwryxk9etygOgcKmSx9jKj_tuAoAb_qW2XFJHORPzL7_Xp_lGQHrAJUIsBZki1ut1620=>  the infiltration of "pirates <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A-eTdzWcWk1gUVil164_ojlB9Ljqj3vIk0nHMhL4lCEZukfQjQIV8FEYzQcPdgwGkcvkBWBAZYOk6rHrg58DGV_O9Ho766AobQCWHef1gWMWgSXfuOEZTBQsA91KEK5ATAZ6AcQBo4kCcyrIBjPJY6h9oHyDUVlbcuHwcKIFLLMl9aG84Lswq11> " and other bad actors using ad networks and open source ad serving to send malware to users, and the Annenberg Innovation Lab Transparency Report (which is a repurposing of Google's Transparency Report <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A-rrYwT7Xx3UEj5su3cGgTbEkawOaJgo0-78JMmVXGfg19vn4Sv17U1Qm5YsFxfb-UzsJ-4pjolMXLp3U92f73jaLVPVp2Gc0l3-Tb3ULm7N5wKSD8K1iWiekgukK2akcc=>  - eMarketer eat your heart out!) has tallied some of the big offending services. Among the two listed by the site for last month are Yahoo's Right Media and British firm Propellerads.com as a major provider to infringing sites, reports Mediapost's Laurie Sullivan. Annenberg Lab Director Jonathan Taplin said he "met with both companies to discuss methods and address the issues. Basically, they blocked access from their ad servers, similar to what they do to avoid placement on pornographic sites, he said. Both reduced the number of infringing sites they place ads on." Read MediaPost <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A_fqEf1UzCpIszvnsCo6xZYXHgcWctyIUE7CQQWLj5ciHaeP4Hz7AvCrM9cfOWfiJtd6AoC6iIZPWZIbVJ0UesC65JwpJ-p2aOg4APqVTUOWrwWxQ6Z96gq7jIQq1Q9Y0CWDGaRr1wetlMz9UNb_o-rAFXDES5iANtUqVI8xctS1-FjqzqXBwqjI3HbMcMM1o1KOPYZMX9616D9FWaOeoPtMezLMcib5DO0mn6bhJb-XvjXCNf7DWLp> . And, get the February report from Annenberg (PDF). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A8lgiEr4bAatXFMdSYC73_OpSVQwquRFHgy9UTEQ4ImC4c8vyW0K9CXu9QhpvaGev-SETWDu3F2CyqH6skWR3RhBTtP3GrTIL-t4luniUqlsajzCY5Rv4CfxGTdyr4pRicX0r1cZNeXdL2LM-6JSfbkl7mcbDpMwZyGwIpDNc9v2EhFB1s9NUnN> 


Ads API + FBX


Two great tastes that taste great together? In a single-advertiser impact study, Nanigans analyzes $1.2 million in sales revenue from one mega-retailer and concludes Facebook Ads API and FBX ads work best when combined. "After being retargeted through FBX, customers entering the remarketing pool through native Facebook audience targeting purchased 89% more in sales revenue than those who entered the remarketing pool through non-Facebook channels." More.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A9m7xkyceYLLnyc4RZXB314IZ8oiIbcl5MjdPg4iWCB_EygAOpXueaHop8W5l5gn0CPxURWarCC96tEaC16AOXHKt-h9RHm2GwKQ6KG09r4Q_X8qudEqmvu2hoTNcOOzb7WO0tRK2_-nvv66Rc6dgjHUNr7fcBazc3T3Kz_sNvpm7OdqCEVym3bUkCqiAPXbT4=> 


Yahoo's Mini Mobile


Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer has put a premium on making money from mobile. But AllThingsD's Kara Swisher says the company has a long ways to go to make mobile revenue a reality. Citing unidentified sources inside the company, Swisher says direct mobile revenue hovers only around $125 million annually, mostly from search revenue on mobile devices. "While users are consuming lots of Yahoo Web pages on their phones, which could technically boost the sales numbers higher, rendering most desktop-created ads on mobile is not the same thing as the significant mobile revenue Yahoo needs to generate," she opines. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A_aKppPfTafDOx4OfTqJRYqP7Hx2L7W8L_9vcSgGEhMhNnB4znR4CyQ5x0FslixBLlQy2CNkD2LGeBNBGJrKWB-dtFv4knSYbdWh9Ryn9C32SDVP_psCrnNg759ikAKMD2QAhG66Hyg3A5RFqlbetOn67wl0aYfHAfKt02OKJssXVK7qlyfk4MFCbDGxQh8y9MA7bpdJfXGdQmwIx8Cm93uPKXiabenJcUtkbI9vviz51x2gz_FCdhwPrIXnXCvuIFfs-pVCq6hCQ==> . 


Make My Stack


On Adweek, Tim Peterson examines the ad tech "stack" of Google's DoubleClick Digital Marketing platoform (DDM). He talks to GroupM media agency Mindshare and asks an exec to compare the Google offering: "...why Google's ad tech stack over Adobe's? 'From our perspective, [DDM's] strength in ad serving and being able to have more clout with networks and partners to get to work with them was an advantage to us because then we could work with more partners,' said Danny Huynh, [the agency's managing director of digital and client leadership]." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A_tr3XvIl9dtfffFFHv6Gj2vTar9NWP820KtzLr3-DtVmeCeXPCKmtklzpNSpq4vVU4Xq-bJxMpgnckGPX0yjloiHXE-JYnFCtTBt1jhCIm28A4ySANPLinCpZdq7-1TEjcaJpeOH9uiEQzuX157_TIsrb8gFfAucJPqsQTwytZ3w==>  And, read Huynh's Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A9NjRdb29pURCpUYbNgo3tmX43nECml-9fO-jgOdPUKv0kixvIZO1s7gdgnSZK0OJ4tcsXYUWk2RgrW7jR9CHCFOidyFA-FyixUvC0k4JCTScaANIuaRLb6y9Qu-m2x6sRTBy3lY5suHjyAUKNEXFZ1hxd2hSzP4fSJ0cRbMFynn1HKwAohX7LQA5kAW_8RoK--iXluFLshxg==> &A on the DoubleClick For Advertisers blog.


Atomic Ads


In a weekend post on TechCrunch, Sharethrough CEO Dan Greenberg and his VP of strategy James Navin outline how marketers and publishers should approach various flavors of native ads: "What ties these seemingly disparate ad products together is one common theme: The ad's visual design and user experience are native to the site itself, and these native ad placements are filled with quality brand content of the same atomic unit (videos, posts, images) as is natural to that site." Go nuclear <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A9xjuSHifv2StSKDvfcN17kd1ljXKg818LBWxrGN36pZrl1Cptm-bhFZUuhwmGTybUz2wFftDyEjix4Og9QR0RWGi5t9elmBVaZmNT6S01rLMBFmc7Hj3I27j6xgaUcLimoS-3wZhjpJ_5EP1zcMx6WC8KTS7OJY3dgT_0OYLrWvBusmeBgn5l3GBc1X7Fti6OhaOif0rYPMw-5qCye92Ye> .

Online/Offline Disconnect


On Harvard Business Review, Marketshare CEO Wes Nichols blames "siloed" thinking when it comes portioning out spending that short-changes the web and continues to fill TV coffers. "[Marketers] mistakenly think they have a handle on how their advertising actually affects behavior and drives revenue," Nichols says. "But that approach is backward-looking: It largely treats advertising touch points-in-store and online display ads, TV, radio, direct mail, and so on - as if each works in isolation." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001FDa2BvrC0A_FWZ5a-eTRRgrqAEMn0ltsPFwv5mE83n1fE55JhRu_t8I9O4srD8wpQNRCua7XWtIBA5IIyOAoY2tgtYmCohQF-wRTFbhd5RTRuUz4csdjaXQavwAt44JQswo9AidrvQVjSerqfdFZnA9Ze6-ZSPrn> .

FBX Results (Continued)


In a lengthy Q&A with Inside Facebook's Brittany Darwell, Facebook measurement guy Sean Bruich talks ads. Facebook Exchange (FBX) is one of many subjects as he comments, "(Direct-response) advertising on Facebook is a lot like DR advertising in the rest of online. We've seen this with FBX. People thought, 'no way Facebook works as a direct response channel, people aren't looking for anything while they're there.' That was totally the meme, and we launched FBX and turns out it works great." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5Qg73sLAoHTp9-9QTNFq7CabrUxqclaJnoUthQ8ZSuK9W-3iElyCBbMpnjCezskFhAYZ6ByFkqk1GrkjSUHNwvvAUx5clitjhVJ8teqz_Yd-_pr7ToRg9WZA1CUEuBcQ7QVlIMYSLVi1SAN4O_IlNRrm96aT64eANsGkElfo_5iITErpWWTIt-wGgyaCVQezMszi9NZvxa5wovOL0Ify0ozMELv6PNa1L2lRVA_qQZyc3kTePY7Cf-vt6Fqc2fxwA=> . Adobe apparently agrees and said yesterday in a blog post that FBX conversion rates were significantly above the average for the eight most popular supply sources (including FBX): "After only one month in beta, FBX deliv­ered a con­ver­sion rate (leads/clicks) that is approx­i­mately 70% higher, and a cost per lead that is over 50% lower, than the aver­age for all eight ad sup­ply sources." But it was only the second best performing source. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5UGM-Id5XdzMuetjddjhrwKLafJu3eFDR3DUidsUqIagMR55ecre8QVzkIRuw2laM7Bq928PhcFqJXRM-oR_duDE_3Ysc-HeZG3wxXtRvV_ZV-6guB0ErIXF-CKYjpF3_YcSICNdu_aINsCj-8Q6SXl88entyWBftJ9_s1ZApfYqQMn59dGChegUTcpY_Zellh1_lgaKm5SI9_AW7oz9r4hMlbPI5SqdWnxzPdAPq-n89IPaIdPGbS55FSUp1n4Kvv23OD_r8KMcbYl3HCC98I>  


Direct to Client


Are agencies in jeopardy? Or are they - as Rishad Tobaccowala says <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv7wK8rJ01GZZuEOYgsvjP6Xpa5S2lFwW0kDjG59yFZPDh1RTexF-5jM23DohPJKS2OIyrmdMy6K5sHoocxu02KeuuE6K3zEDLOhjBwUjJB8W0bflInj75TOooTWRKZ2VQ4xBgvyYv5ddS0nul42xiHhhpZdG0xe2v9AwzmNQFHDuQ7Sx60KQNfoBIh-h78pqDiXIjshZXaQJqkbYiBBlGaqpCX5VpMAo18=>  - infinitely adaptable cockroaches that will always find a niche? In a piece taking the former point of view, Digiday offers a litany of agency painpoints including the rising tendency of marketers to bring marketing functions in-house. Social and programmatic media are both mentioned. Jack Daniels global marketing director Carmen D'Ascendis says, "I don't believe you have to be a digital native to get digital. How does Fisher Price figure out toys? They don't have kids doing their marketing, that's for sure." More.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv6TTn2NlnFa8c_oablxY0r98DVK9xZzY66VRc6DGT3QqQiyCH83zp6o1X5TvK7xB5vXoGhL9x7ue7ZqCg3RJehp4jPXuc_d1GarxmkpLOMZWVgHdoOnjnemW60RxCE7iptE9HUGeXdy6yFP7Nfzy0NDO_sCf20r3nWLLs89_ajfeFWW3S1wobNrUoYi9IVzMzFaoxEJN3bp2g==> 


Conquest Now


Demandbase cuts right to the chase with a new feature set for its targeting platform - "Come target your competitor's audience according to its tech attributes." From the release: "For example, a brand that sells technology complementary to Salesforce.com <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5M0u8Tp4eZ_FDXzG_B9WJ2L8eUY3jErSXBdzfqQ7SE72kQUbDMn627mGz7lbLzEUecTc9TcqRzv8-285baXs36xNd3koWqca7Y9Vg4wdmKdw==> 's CRM software can now run a campaign targeting ads only to 'Fortune 1000 companies that use Salesforce CRM.'" Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv7mDawSLOgX8rHZVE8HzqeQzYsxH2-pTif-IX8G_e-uE2w0xGDnhTwqBGbmdH7aVu4Es6O5GYfdBcqgyMuuK1b2ptr84qaNhCc4jREsc8R1uDDzL42kBOeZbt4icqjmC9ED0FHHq5e0PhuLBMBjj5aIGi-tnrCkfcDSvV1chrUGauwLFnLIoJpDeZPrYiepEPfJ13572FsNoghOujIUyxnJtBC069a7aN9WkcQth5MvgBJM7AR9kuYgjZmomLI0Xc4zGSVbyZo4jygW4jG4dH_AdM9Sct8Wxr6Rq-32Iy-ohA==>  Not an ad network -an attribute network. 


"We've Been Approached By Yahoo"


PubMatic CEO Rajeev Goel discusses his sell-side platform in an interview on Bloomberg and admits Yahoo has discussed possibly acquiring Pubmatic. See it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5fHGnMCttZz261AEdNUI4HAJfReMQunStHLWUX7mJvJ2eGFQm-o47vGDH9tNYaP68gYmvPynPJvwMlQ0DpsUvHbEraco0cXrkyPFYUOsKYiQqY6TAJnS78i1JJPDbsD3wep5w4UFyGjkxa4qGotgkzOP41mR5jLHG59WK0A9D52Q3NonMGoUciR8U3Aer5RdCDWpw8E3gqvTdlWRJCxRM9>  Goel strikes all the right notes - even including "art & science" in his narrative. PubMatic also released some data about its platform yesterday including, "By Q4 2012, Real-Time Bidding (RTB) had come to represent nearly 31% of all paid impressions - nearly doubling its share year-over-year - and 48% of all revenue." Read it all. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5GLt8EXxF60GyfvCVjLBXIeJwY34d2cd0sg5i_qgk3pJ0Cj8Aehjv3dyyPjRRED5GV5n14S64hPpyE7Aiy6R9fBFiDhz8IhjiknBrKIiA1NQoCGTs66UfQ4FWHuormfWQSE83YAcbX-AvWJ2ouKE2QqVpR27g4ccn9JAaK1RGoxOsfEF5XeDdaMugD0nJpM8DXNzW_YVPhvT0wDXT_JyGc3Ku8jEhQrQ0dIy9iWk7oqzWYQcksDpZE8uEBa9B0luE=> 


Search And Display, Together At Last


Perhaps it's the Valentine's Day vibe in the air, but Bill Dinan, president of analytics provider Telmetrics, says that mobile has brought display and search closer together. Writing on MarketingLand, Dinan says that display was driven into search's arms because mobile marketing demands the key tenets of successful search ads, such as "establishing secondary action strategies" to drive user engagement and local targeting. "These components will help mobile display become a true source of mobile monetization - and, when paired with mobile search, the sky will then be the limit for monetizing the overall mobile ad industry," Dinan contends. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv4pB_fezjtRllXFdLWx2Y_TIh6-tvIvt9EY9bo8G8vzqyLUKMrqa2OurE20qqnoYaRPnDZUfxmYeIgSGRNGNFCQiAaTqTFHDAfOTTiQF4O3OBgK_Gzmh7ZX7gomCMtYaBdaOWbPFKNgSVUAFgg6tzLOq4zfeUlAMVwT7PiCXaS00Qq6HpjukdcU_kITHkK_KZmA6JIciRlTXLsrUDCNar-3> .

Networks' Low Quality Reach


Aggregate Knowledge, which claims to be a media intelligence versus a data management <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5IqeDEDjEgMjDP1zb6T6C6rVagPoBfbbthAj_n-U5NEmeJC-TbP6JggPFQUKpru4v9g5rnSsfo_WCg8F2-xRd-YS09NnRo6HsNv7J_4_LRKJuDncxza3yAL8Px-85q7E9rMrW0XAdZRyhYNJuJbmuiAsPmIu_YSSE=>  platform, reveals in a release that over $100 million was spent through its systems in 2012's Q4. Also, its Global Media Intelligence report says the company looked at 35 billion impressions in Q4, it found that "networks and exchanges perform 35 to 69 percent below the indexed average in reaching high-quality users that can consistently be marketed to." When looking at which channels are seen most in the upper part of the attribution funnel, social and portal influences are the most undervalued. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5ep2OY_nQoj-6drGOsQLT9OQ70YAsefqbuB1P9KOp9U9BJTvYQQlrIi5cyXZruFqYDkdASa95AFCzsJsKoqFhKqmgnIUAXLh7Lyb_Qvljd6se8bC0HzBZLAjFpr7BnXsCrcaUe_CdwNgwfT1wSLOWZLcFbDaYWhBKoMJtNLMbreA-2YV6XK_DqPXhNUawMtK8cnl8zqP-BlkFB8ueFN6Au4a5h_2nyeNw=> . 


Counting Ads


An average of 3 in 10 ads are never rendered in-view says new comScore research - comScore's 2011 AdXpose purchase <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv5mEMp_80nqb5zzg5gfOUJoJeUNvKZ0s3dJFxszyKHGLw2ZpY4liXeygtgdwFDYINX_r43XcGHIGSTu-rE3OroTm-Dn_fyNCH32kpd8g0v5dOTAE3gW_O6jXsRwILx1DgBiwNFFKLQa7iLssR2ViVC0f-Gv3d0UMGxz57ZP6pVg-l9y837iwolcS1v_5TG811sOUs7NdjWzQQ==>  is likely defining the numbers. "Through the continued adoption of a viewable impressions standard, the market is beginning to embrace a digital scarcity model that better aligns monetization with the value created by the inventory," comScore says in its Digital Future in Focus. Download it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv4n5z4o65MvP3clPPu5zfVUctf86f9WG3RAbzn3_2LO3WQWrhDr37vQD3mQLBwaUfAIamGU6hqOloKw5rTy4xLJtA5hDxHrKreeLA6NfhX5psUIQMu_3le1x0Sf83QtXCA-pZatOz6WJ2RAjBpnD5Z9v5r-dIfGldg5FWHMRcBkcQ==>  or just read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011euipjceXv7vv375Jlbtts4GIEJnrj23Z9tLtpRg7DYlYtowSh8axMUd27UYQQ7jje16h_FnN8DmrLPUfiZu73fYkDhTZYc4dzi42jyCp3Ide-fUMCJPWycTUuPnNuvbbTlfQOLOiDSZBj0MlQL8GGedLJoEgCqrdJ5GE3NyPB2H-b3P9JsCq3OniG5EIX_qJ8npDLYp1VLt9RSvj-i_zhI4k-XaYCx0e3jv2FqIfNEvsr2Xq7rp0w==> . 


Curious Sales


In a post on his company's blog, Upstream Group's Doug Weaver dares to unearth "Curious George" from the depths of his readers' childhood memories. [PRIMAL SCREAM HERE] Counseling the sales leader, he writes, "Focus (...) on fostering one simple quality within your sales team: curiosity. While almost no one can 'present a customer into buying,' virtually everyone can improve sales outcomes through genuine curiosity."  News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS2DI8SobU8rf5l5fLA0A-tSey2qZmnOMkBoNsHejiw4qquOWZZ15ZqyXxi9WZbjoKEd2sXXGFZkQ1iOD4kHr7rS_AIJP-fc_Ej4XwCXRWiS6FQwEGQdHWC2SFVMLFgT4_c=> .

 

$400 Billion+ Digital


Google SVP Nikesh Arora tosses a juicy number out for the advertising world at All Things D's conference. Arora stated, "There's currently about $800 billion in the global advertising market today. That's a very large number, but online advertising accounts for less than $100 billion of that number. There is a reasonable probability that over 50 percent of advertising goes online in the next five years." He's waiting for connected TV. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS0C6WU3Isp_dxE9p4l8CvKb4MmkiIY00kSt5xtH36mVFKH1T_3Pt0WP-msCLAUPMfip9RMXyKpRbLYfbN47l-nzcSp7-ZxmLAMGlpMeSIwrWrF0VAog0ZjiBBohGY7S06T3xzFe61ZcBTxcG-trll12QeE-fayS-iy1uKVdKJlq3V0yfxWE724KfXORu1yz56KN3z5V1NbCzlQl545-8TdQ>  Have things accelerated for the GOOG? This prediction dovetails with former Google CEO Eric Schmidt's 2011 prediction <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS21CctUs4B_y2doyBak3PE9AxXaFJkaPrJC-FRUgSqilICG2pBfp1ITKKA2qKRH5d8QU0OZzsxJ-0n6jjudsY4ZSLFm-vrx1-iNNQOiKF9dWtTUxYAKkJv-kCMjJncRy36do4lHWfGsxgXVbSNR-wtfFqVea2QCu72H3yO8nps201RVnzGaLNtys8mcUNRRBvOaBBbjGC2o1vQWNYhIKxx9DQIh5uiNEb4=>  that "online display" would reach $200 billion in 10 years. 


Marin Files For IPO


The worst kept secret in the conjoined worlds of Wall Street and ad technology finally became a reality yesterday as buying platform Marin Software filed documents for an initial public offering (IPO) that will bring the company $75 million in proceeds. The company does not say how many shares it will sell so it's hard to tell what the company thinks it's worth. Marin got its start with search engine marketing - which remains its mainstay product - and, the company had $4-5 billion in ad spend reportedly pulsing through its 2012 platform pipes. In recent years, the company has added social (i.e. Facebook ads, etc.), mobile and display to its repertoire. See the S-1. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS1LFhN9iqzZFLomC38KXoQWjuHJHkmEe39oPnbBGEYQ9JwbRAOCOWcDxMpmKtMwdpJSQ_v3ygMlMxRnsEDduyMImrEyiV0KHkLrMwpq3gKz0C57gHCsH53Uz7tiSzskV4FBBwiGvVQEMYPwpV4Ynoij-oF4Wx36ykfysRxMvO8K9EdeioUvpeJolUWbMnD47ptim2U9EJcGG-5es8JsjQWD>  Looking at revenue, for the nine months ending September 30, 2012, the company reported $42.5 million in revenue resulting in an $19 million loss. 


Money For Location


Verve Mobile has taken a $14 million C round led by Qualcomm and others to drive growth of its location-based ad network. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS01Te32v8UGnx9utziTZnYy7nDyAKcL8FcJJWkRExg6pqeZ1vmsrsXbqDYMF7TA2iSi9Hp-eUDerQEZc0U0hGX6RTJfhVfo8LzcgvqalrkgYm-t4nvCghEbjGuCMqMU6VQ17rEuxjN2_UFT8IrjkWt4F_VTlua2zYoNnDYpPs87oGH3i_gUnA_h5CN9GRe9gNN2kWAe5A5HMkUsnJYmJHQdh-2snnkvYWO02KOIb5h3hqinMFaZkxvS_CUeZFdGLatrsG4CsvdWFQ==>  Back in August, CEO Tom MacIsaac told AdExchanger <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS3AOID-2gqpuNRoxW1U60xz7ZzXonPGe345wjpYmZdNVyfkywX95guMbEEZSpS5bkhvqXMjzbZte_3QcATxg_rQoIecrEsliibJcc2ggjEMUqRkSuuwAgg4QgrKbo-RNOzkp55j_B84KJ8a6Pddv25AJWm9xZzdsiHWFjyKQdM2lx2fwg6qdZNJd23xWjn7W2bl2Ta2Zh6DufNrwBW-ihsW6Qo5XH39nxMuPAuGstSd4Q==> , "We have gone from 20 to 65 employees in the last 18 months. Our 2012 revenue will be approximately 3x our 2011 revenue (which was about 3x our 2010 revenue) and we should reach profitability later this year." On the currently hot question of whether tablets should count as "mobile," MacIsaac offers a strong argument that they do. Hey, the couch is a location too. 


App Ad


Microsoft is shooting the moon with new "Ads in Apps" for Windows 8 environments. Blog post. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS08NQ_9gOE_B55ynaaZ3P9c0sX3IfBaFF0M5DNna2SNbdsUqXHHh4Ms3hrKL9QjL-H_RxUyQ6YZ-hgjwArzZNpliwkyj9-UGm0shrNIotmx2QqVKXa65qB5PRoZzryBn7kw9GC0cG6qvLzLgvDfrUcLXfHhSYymeOUoHiKlAAiHlYqEdE_pEwYE3BQQSkwIJGirmSDy-DJlCk-UOVcMrRmW1RpCkTaV1qAuQqFusi6Y1cCSZr0OBYeys7wxCBmng_XwjnYjBWCEYF9flQoqaVyx>  AdWeek praises it: "Delta's ad placement invites users to swipe up, rather than left and right-a simple twist, but one that looks to capture a central theme of the Delta's current campaign." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS3-x36hQYj-m0gkSPpjFgaJhNrTPdjwlG3E_JfniHpOQhQE_8FJcuMbY99qF8iEBLnyO5XqNxGs-SRaJEsxhmMlyYBmNW1xo1OOxRATyrZbUhlgQgdE1dIhjPFIRghNUTt1SoD0J6yQvcBmtvck1p2wWOqi99B9sfxKoO1XYe9abk5AQYUY7PY-wipIUeZMYPw=>  The challenge, as always with Microsoft, is achieving scale. 


Linking In Mobile


JP Morgan analyst Doug Anmuth reviews his meeting with LinkedIn CFO Steve Sordello in a research note. On LinkedIn's mobile opportunity, he says, "We believe Sponsored Content could be the primary way that LinkedIn monetizes the mobile news feed, for smartphones in particular. As LinkedIn becomes more of a professional publishing platform with both organic and shared content, we believe it becomes easier for the company to add relevant ads with context into the news feed. Early testing of Sponsored Content has mostly been around white papers, but we look for this advertising, based content to expand."
