Pondering Time Inc. Sale


Time Inc. just went through a series of large, across the board layoffs. But apparently, lowering headcount isn't enough to balance out shrinking print revenues, as parent Time Warner is talking to potential acquirers of part of the publishing unit, Fortune reported. Women's magazine publisher Meredith Corp. appears like the most likely candidate to take on entertainment/lifestyle titles People, InStyle, and Real Simple. "It is not clear why Bewkes might want to keep Time magazine, Fortune, and Sports Illustrated," Fortune says. noting the first two aren't that profitable. "And Sports Illustrated has clear value for Time Warner's Turner Broadcasting System, although in the past the two have disagreed on digital strategy." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS1pyVR0NNQS4x8-HPw50-_mjJ3iaH1cGwnpXaXqr5H8Dd7Z1dFDhKocUx7PS6tOvKzVTLPnturTD9X8y4akm2rk57IVr0i3GzS0i2Db_aJx4WT82Qe4zk1DFiQITa-p9iGHiAFReg20OqtjDiPRDhcTpqFARvZVHej4k4KSS-Zflw==> . 


It's ALIVE


The Yahoo-Aol-Microsoft display ad alliance is still ALIVE. A post on the Yahoo ad blog says that Microsoft is joining Aol and Yahoo in a similar "alliance" deal for Canadian inventory. This is the first peep out of the alliance in months. More to come? Read the brief post. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS3leZxbLZF4gMWxqLLdGRliPHQWG52n-5C65aYdIS8rod8OaStTzTlodykp7ZdonJvht4juLo62C2CdzRPi_rx3R3IZ3Nvn40VlVM8XnHQsvzvD4yKxQx848MxI1o6M4UNWTyPhl3-RMagKlMPYxq3PuzJf_sjSPvQ3c71OC5vwgq4dbKnXMeydA3MKI1VsqOEccl-JmocMsnFsGeJUwKroWLD0lx9H80KCIARrJRZMBw==> 


Tracking Leads


Hey, this sounds like something a Salesforce product does... now LinkedIn is in the email tracking game. (The plot thickens!) MediaPost's Laurie Sullivan explains how presentations can now be shared and tracked in real-time through LinkedIn's Slideshare site: "Marketers upload content into SlideShare to share publicly or privately and attach it to an email. Send Tracker follows how they interact with it. Users receive a real-time notification via email when recipients look at the content. It records how much time the person spent on each page and whether they clicked or copied the content." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS1wpkj1Ki1y9tpsuxLqUtEmXxFQzZ9G6__qLv-tc2RnWI3BswvKcEpatwFvk6YkLiCQmamhxJ_sgU6efzjT2iCD3qAE2ZFwKZPmF1t7umEFuHyzU5cBML-4-0Ty9NdrBL9aCd2I7jeTNk-OtSSnhxI5Q8E0wmKy1e4IeilchwN-dnf_U2hVD2v9DAUf1qR83sFdw6mHVBsICvW3GDzlhl6dE177Q4OK26M=>  And, read the SlideShare blog post on  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS2hXmQkjD0Do135d7XBuI4PJCjTTd2RKg2pVJeghEkiM7QNZUisFApJiuF73zsToorwxt9-pXzHclzJjz3dq4OiYdM3ynF8D6agx0deVDommF5Mm-mYxHy47JR6hbpBDw9kel9yb3UPuagIFBMxoyAqftqQA_q2_sENHxFk5kYN5sxiUaooSrhfredg2I5YigPfKzPWzKWylnRb11oB43BLlcAp0vAumHUlVZYgVwdMCg==> "Send Tracker."


AOL Goes Gdgt


It's been awhile since AOL bought a content site, but the company has decided to expand its publishing side offerings in the tech arena by acquiring technology reviews site gdgt <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS1Xt31Q_ILjfbUov3UT7wv8xOyPtv7KEgjM8JFGr8EMZzHJukrC4EihhoDrfx1w0voFuDElf-yRYvaW_nxjykUmfBKvGMcs87g=> , reports Techcrunch's Alexia Tsotsis and Ingrid Lunden. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001kWW3h3_BOS1Yt67OqTkpklDXxTkxpydW1OgtGmiThnHK1KXjYOXzWv46By184mOtF-l7yYMV9RNpKcwfrZuj6qsDusf0qJiJ87CTPF0UjdpUZ7cEK5Df4ewF68l6LUFnatiGmTby3Df29J04071iEIZ84y-youYZzgxa24mVmooZa-mKFfrQ7AVVQkRGkrPaEByi7fuHJvrpfqUoQfbBlg==> . In addition to owning Techcrunch, AOL also has Engadget in its stable of sites. It also marks the return of Ryan Block and Pete Rojas, gdgt's co-founders and former Engadget editors, to the AOL fold. "We didn't leave Engadget (or AOL) because we were unhappy, we left to do gdgt because at the time it was tough to build something that was clearly not editorial," Block told Techcrunch. "That's obviously changed, and we're excited to be able to continue to invest in and grow gdgt, while also bringing a lot of the stuff we've built to the rest of AOL Tech."

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRmDIvVgpAydtDsn8ToqH3WPUas58XamX5ay0RNMLNNPivbizF0BCLW8hb9PtnhVDLNCSmSdGxn9_fbsA6SHK6WvVdDp6oLPrAlHwBhZgS0xDtarB-BUR-aHrdDeTyziLYE=> .

 

The Exchange Can Be Larger


At The Goldman Sachs Technology conference, Yahoo! CEO Marissa Mayer submitted to questioning on her company's strategy. In response to a question about Yahoo's ad tech position she said, "Ad tech is fundamental to what we do. It's been an underappreciated asset, the Right Media exchange works really well. We've got a very good, premium salesforce. The exchange can always be larger. We already have notable supply in the exchange, it's something that works really well for advertisers, it's something we're going to keep investing in. Like search, ad tech marches on. We do need to invest in the technology that makes programmatic bidding easy and self service easy." Read the live recap on the WSJ (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRnIZUs8hPZ6cR48bePPuGBIg1dMwlfaEV_cMTkcGh4guIObEjuNhi5rhEM458Wo8mRWvR0xrXW-VH3JmCswJJ0zdRO3hiGPd3D8_vXAlDIEghXdJJE1_DDEExutCss9zyKI4TxEPoBf2cWyQ4reQIuQyGCeK2roJkHow1Ojvx1biQWVtaygc9ohNVAx3oFku6XQ7L5Iih27jJAw6IeJugMk> . 


Facebook Mobile Pennies


Wall Street analysts expected a big influx of mobile ads into the Facebook news feed would juice Q4 revenues in a big way. Instead, revenue growth was merely solid, and as a result its stock price is off 11% so far in February. BTIG said in a note, "We believed advertising revenues were set to notably exceed investor expectations, as we saw Facebook pushing a significantly higher ad load into users' mobile news feed during the fourth quarter." MarketWatch story. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRntpdF1py_P9W5TxaaiDu0HQtAwrPkatcQUvu1SEXp6SaCeqAIqzrmoROSGOx1cMgz5ATyY_mkS21bsF4tWobUpVZG1YayN0eo9zWYzRm_SfxqlGSckRCPIJspRL4o-6vJGVp2XUAm_7z3-GzBkDi4LVojjQ-JRIHc_pwGH-F-iL1sGa0A7W8q2JzMYtPzsVzw=> 


Digilant on FBX


The indie trading desk formerly known as Adnetik (and formerly under the Havas Media umbrella) is up and running on the Facebook Exchange. Digilant says it is the first partner to bring FBX targeting to brands in Mexico. It has outposts in both Mexico and in Brazil, which are the #5 and #2 Facebook markets globally according to SocialBakers <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRmIbnNIDuCnG4lY0GnrnnXGc2GCt2pEWAID1T9NDevHgRJ5XmMUblNPyaqE8t-kRL0TLGBMVtKWQQkTv2qJzQwcCmDoqcimJDpBrEBfSHn5Ekkbu2j78girnyPu_pows_z-ofhHSqiTCA==> . Brazil is a big focus for at least two other FBX partners, Turn and Triggit. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRltlGtXm7LMbC2K57fQgornhP2Y4pcak4hKvD_recSDVmZnA38fDjPgW4-x6eyfQsGnfg14vR6NgPn4zRw3PmTjTKeEncVM0GRyq53Ct2kBKbzw7khjnmsWUllpBcUivVetrLSPiCuBbO8z7ZnQlJ-6scf3ajHapihvXwd1h0vkkOHV_i5KE-ff> 


More Yahoo, More Mayer


Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer is making good on her intentions to buy small companies in areas like mobile. The latest deal, for an undisclosed amount, is with discovery app Alike. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRkmZ3TuSv1ElGpbD734pEkTVw7gXayFaY6yi0vIoNd5X2D9w-if69sORBGi5e57pW1RnIq5-j9wUn6RRngKCol9ytD2Qim1yTY=> . It comes on the heels of other Yahoo purchases the last few months, including another recommendation app called Stamped, and social sharing tool Snip.It. "We were very impressed by the team and their approach to building personalized experiences. The entire Alike team will join Yahoo!'s mobile organization in San Francisco and Sunnyvale," a Yahoo rep told Mashable's Seth Fiegerman. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRlKCCyeZdIgDMD79MQNejAmCAdmsUEg6-Ey2Wm9uheF3XWO3w-_AzeOZbqV7CbZCfkvgXLTjhf4633Y9OH_d5ZYnproHt6CdpUhe4ZsK8_-xgip7d7IRyoAsPh44UtTn8Ajd7UcpclscXQr_GWoarg2> . 


Simulmedia Raises Again


It was less than a year ago that targeted TV ad provider Simulmedia raised <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRmIfyuIdwju6MUuESK50P46g1JE1rXZ4Slzr855ujiI5a_jy_FRn65bX5NKoscyuVAqxb40LxPykATjOojPGXqjrSjMY6CpFc5KqfPQxqdGIlBmR6eIIfDDNkvwEUSl9jfhvFwa-PS1HF36jryJ731EPltEKnH_LZU=>  a $6 million round, but CEO Dave Morgan has decided to add another $5 million from the company's venture backers. Read the SEC filing <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRlmasG_PWphvzaDobjgtDpD38knxdbxz-2TCkLCxi9lYoZC84cRqCYCktAfg8TBRAjkxSY7dlANnPgGmGHzhdp_fL7sqLXHuWa6c8wTRY2v1A9lX6q0-HW4bR2WON9aBgvRHiH9ehGd2B4_XAgbj9lILZ6ED-kq8xX4wpAd07A2tUdDJWUuygbKR5yVpCGip7up3mC_RItDQjF9f5OB4Wz8> . Simulmedia has taken in a total of $32 million since opening its doors nearly four years ago. But why not just start another formal round instead of an add-on? Morgan tells Techcrunch's Ryan Lawler that he "prefers to raise small inside rounds as the company continues to grow, instead of doing a large mezzanine round" because it gives the company greater flexibility on pricing. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRmG3LPhFoOvYnnPYqTrKhA-j3ikQiZw_MIQmU_WR3EEyUr5s0suytjH1a_cphZiwezaruf5cZg5JKwK5SwBnCyj52U9i1E7a5yyZurd9YW_U6a_Vg38u66U7B7WaUSIVPmSA0cvO7DC_X14HdGe0_DECe02Ki5NzrY=> .

Stopping Banner Blindness


Joe McCambley, co-founder/creative director at interactive ad shop The Wonderfactory, muses not-too-fondly about the early days of internet advertising and helping to create one of the first banner ads at Modem Media for AT&T. He's proud of that, but not proud of what has proliferated. Agencies and marketers still don't get that online is lean-forward as opposed to lean-back (people go to the web to do something, not watch something). "The future of advertising lies not in ads as we've known them, but in helping all those people on all those elevators get stuff done, or entertaining them," he says in a post on HBR. "The companies and people that understand content, and utility, will be the ones to thrive." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001qC-UzE28pRmOLuUz7i7l21onnbDsf26iYBjtxEn4_B4tvgahqsfVXFN3TsiRZrcfmDAco9VgPIDHDZIcrpnGmlkdKzJfoH1dIxOlb650PW3-dIoK3iBClRf9FYmYWr2_pU6e3ubNCtoF-IYiqsxXMCjfmgaO0paou_JbLrRr-ddG5Zloiqsamw==> .

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t-DRyLOsbYbwRKFvx49roUs2Zv23fOjWVh01vN8NeWZA0q7mK9_CN_wkUTE_MxmL3_QpElndHClbUg_Xf5GoqkSZkHCgLWDHb5V3MEI6TKVs4RaBKtzopzrGpTdXmKdDZo=> .

 

Twitter Adds Commerce


Many publishers these days are thinking about commerce to add to their advertising and content strategies. Twitter is no different as yesterday the ever-enterprising American Express announced a new partnership with the popular micro-blogging service. The Wall Street Journal's Shira Ovide explains, "American Express card holders who connect their card numbers to their Twitter accounts can post on Twitter to trigger a purchase of select products (...). The program will roll out over the next few days." The particulars of the use case aside, presumably Twitter gets a percentage of the transaction. Read more (subscription) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t8BMsV_JSCFq0CiZFJ5TVbxnTWg-5OjwDTa8Ok5TvOoDnl8ofFoOfTIYTHpDmH8fNvEoLVRYLFE-c_dOitcISqmI-tGKXQk4GXv5OJC0cBttxbjdRi_XnqWI_i1XyheHnFX0Luu0U31UKu5i1oz1PebQLx_LCquv9ohS0nSe4xN975QU59NrY0FHh3JuKGQG9pe-O9RihUOyef5qoBL837Z> . Twitter just added a bottom-of-the-funnel, intent data stream. Retargeters, right this way!


A Wary Eye On RTB


Mail Online, the mostly independent digital sibling of the UK tabloid, The Daily Mail, is positioning itself as more of a global news site and has the traffic to back up that goal (comScore says it has monthly traffic of 50 million uniques, higher than the NYTimes.com). With such a huge audience and hundreds of posts a day, this site would be tailor-made for the power of real-time bidding, right? CRO Rich Sutton isn't so sure. "On the one hand, you can't fight city hall," he tells Digiday's Brian Morrissey. "There aren't a ton of case studies on the efficacy of RTB. It's more efficient, it delivers more for less cost per thousand, but the jury is out about how effective it is for brands." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t_0IAlyLqq63j-msmD4qTnBGwgZzDZ5sBlQtYXIrBe6H2jyBCJLA0hPEKH61ONj1yrLZH8KbDP-AMzcFlrVc0G1C7MA1RTPPictde2N33MCnMnc8Q0HGXrMNcGVl1J1rr_g8D0VAa7fX9P5WgZJQU5ot76VIXy8bjA=> . 


More On Twitter API


There's been much talk lately about potential new ad products from Twitter, including an RTB Exchange (AdExchanger story <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t9POvOquAOjTogb_KflSsZwtA58m5XOnsmKhS0RLzRNJPLPzbhnh5X9Wa_a4N9kzXuGGGNPJzqphUvnt85kssrzBZWh8B8FYjC2YLIXtA3kwZjhpF5gnZuj3k4ib5oUCDZO1L1I3cPBzdkHiEyYwIL7mKpmSheE6rJYYJRAT_Ib0SbWtAplGTMC2bDQuvfqoYg=> ) and, more definitively, an Advertising API (TechCrunch report <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t-DV3eF7dtQ7tIHX80YnEkTCJ9AfS1nQHWDjigE1cejqtxdPJaEhmep1qW1_nUoWqiRbNBRscIG8D7A_eB2D91FDb9scGk8Lc53zpnopg5BXfgV14y6w00G6e6980ICq4Cs7AdUeqUwN5tEOYNoHsVWkkbTdyBfRRBhrv1FoybBI2tvvVJ0JZtxEpIprUIJdKh6jLGGjWcMIvRnKqZ2RXYCneW6vqHrvIDEjkEBfgjXBA==> ). AdWeek has more on the API plans, saying the product will be based initially around Promoted Tweets -- not Promoted Trends or Accounts. "An Ad API could be a double-edged sword for Twitter. The company has been extremely careful in limiting ads running in users' streams and ensuring those displayed generate positive feedback from users otherwise they get pulled." Timing for the Ad API is later this quarter. More.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t_aQZESUoUVGIW5OE_B6S64tCaTvMSa2RowQiDOlGjdHvbdAC2ap6tTSWnK-GSuIhpHJ2LQwWUJyud6-ASPhVioVjfexp5U3cSmNeAGEWTUIzB9iy5j7kUNWYkhTvrpCxZ_f_gZx0-sh7qC-Knge7Um-p3zJVPniVnDGezE83sB2dc11blbbUtk> 


EU Data Fears, U.S. Lobbying


The European Union is continuing to look for ways to tighten regulations around consumer privacy and ad targeting and Computer World UK's Glyn Moody is expressing dismay that U.S. lobbyists aren't just influencing the process, they appear to be writing the laws word-for-word. But Moody does see how readily accessible data can be used to turn the tables on lawmakers who are taking dictation. "Thanks to the wonders of modern technology, and the rise of open data that sees all kinds of information made available, it is now possible to piece together a much clearer picture of what exactly our EU representatives are up to," Moody says. Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t8bXTUnjV-gF8tmpwKDUvQuK0poBm6aYNZe1Yr9q1e3Inbf76n9gYuIYwE6EcshpzfIuxUnoeiRiN1hcXJVgyi2K2jdkZJVgpN29tx2Bs-SB8Jq6nqXt8MMnMpzPrGaMvcdEQd15XDUFcSzBsZxrF_R7zOu2lkS8yRajvK1w20DmXCXys0viru-JvD-beWQ0JH-7DEmmvaJqzFM1351I_SOVwzcqKvOY2dEyd1BPhOyGgODyqPcndxtPEmvggJPvUE=> . 


Mobile Exit-er


It looks like Metaresolver CEO Seamus McAteer is about to sell his second mobile ad startup. AdAge reports Millennial Media is close to buying the company, which sells itself as a "clean data" source for programmatic mobile ad buying. McAteer previously sold mobile analytics play M:Metrics to comScore. Metaresolver is less than a year old. More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t_YEuNT6Ho_OfpBZ5RzgwUmD9TB-60Ynb6AG7nTDlwVihr2KqN97OtDoUlydzvGsGmpHinvgCE5qbDg6xy4X0y2__m2qOMJ_Zj5w2Cefw55rg==>

Going Multi-channel (Omnichannel?)


NBC is trying to make its frat boy cable TV outpost, G4, to grow up to be more upscale, so it is rebranding the channel as The Esquire Network, as in the Hearst Magazine title. Aside from cable, the Esquire Network brand will include web, mobile and social experiences that link to the main magazine site, with plans for original web series, apps and TV Everywhere and on-demand access, AdAge's Jennifer Poggi reports. "We are closely tied to its success," said David Carey, president of Esquire parent Hearst Magazines, in an email. "We'll be promoting the Esquire Network across all the relevant properties in the Hearst stable." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t_dVvR4F8qh4q71wN3kTpaDTHWw7TfVh_MydaKJFRjuEMkC9yNuFawILNbRWWtjjibXhyKAKkUGIOoLm0vzIVoJMQdAl0dUYk04LOt88RCa2bt9XMbK0JHr1fD7r50reCP6g_8HugdXdwt38H5gIcKRUYSpG27mEnM8Z8ul8Wq6vQ3TqNFhK791OstCFaDqZYA=> . 



80/20 Reach


Nielsen's Global Head of Advertiser Solutions, Randall Beard, takes Nielsen Wire blog readers on a review of "Reach" in the world of television. It would seem his musings resonate online, too. The 80/20 rule is in effect as he notes that 20% of viewers are "light viewers" - how to reach the people that rarely watch. He writes, "Light viewers tend to be younger, more affluent, better educated and working outside the home. (...) They watch more cable, watch programming at different hours, use DVRs, stream content online, etc. (...) Current media planning tools don't do a very good job of constructing plans to reach these people. That's why TV media plans often end up with approximately 80 percent reach-no matter how much they spend." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001SAuibk6e7t_RLXoVZky3kdC1--lwTdds6UdmDA9R_PeOH6uHbsShrjOSmPNcjVTV4AI0EZHS9iJCdPtiWsmzDRNcJsYW3SNa6i1mGnNLPMNv1XMUurvZD2liev2_JW8xVIwBPsYxDVwRE25n7gFKDqBnXO4Rb_lKu0yH-cPO-O0=> .

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6spmq57JEuDvhn6UpsNeQPYxtZeqX1mBOZFxS96TSiArH8g0xSrGELPOB2C-iryn89VXDrHhrWXjTomAw87beN3azSLHzL_5c5lvKwQWqPnoc07EfTparIKpH64Q-TDrXXw=> .

 

Report: Atlas To Facebook


The eagle has landed - almost. Microsoft is announcing the sale of its Atlas ad server to Facebook as early as next week says Ad Age's Jason Del Ray. He writes, "The acquisition price is not known, but is expected to be less than $100 million, based on prior bids for Atlas, which have been in the $30 to $50 million range.The acquisition would be the surest sign yet that Facebook has designs on becoming an even bigger player in advertising than it currently is now." Pivotal's Brian Wieser wades in with analysis, "The news should be viewed positively, and suggests that Facebook will pursue an ad network, allowing advertisers to reach audiences using Facebook-based targeting criteria across the web. It also increases Facebook's self-dependence around online advertising infrastructure, in a sector where Google has become dominant." Atlas is not the strategic centerpiece it once was. Is this just a test kitchen for bigger "meals" down the road for FB? Full-funnel attribution Facebook-style, here we come! 


Facebook Appvertising ROI


Measuring post-install ROI is a big problem for mobile app developers -- and one Nanigans aims to alleviate with a new tracking product geared to Facebook mobile campaigns. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6soc2IzioTAXrg0Bhs6QI5-Sk5DDDqcqHO7tex19v73e61HkfSXR7X3menPIL-NcUJBykBG9YZRMD-OuVsPzMnp3RAxbsQImqsXjjXmAsDbHHzMzGIqTdgoBFKyMVQCwQcWYCcfxSh999k7W-Bmq-85eLaZHaV0jymlbNV6aJ-LXSWRkRwMFuR9mp4-Xlwo0-Os=>  COO Marc Grabowski tells AdWeek, "We can look at different interest-level targeting, action spec targeting, what Facebook apps people have taken part in or interacted with and overlay that information with performance behavior to give a level of granularity you can't get anywhere else." App developers Fab, TinyCo and Wooga are onboard. More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6sroWFz6wFpWaUpXMB22VKP1iRyJjvbMpBifYu1hS_pC035DeQA_yjSzCpXkEIc6ds2qH9nwLvRuVI6-wrCpp_vtXVD7IbLYVyejCvMdYCB0axt07QcFkIYQKfgFfIdVUqSr686rrpoBuEH3obuZ1wSk-WOinNswinM7lorDjdfM6GY7SnsDCMDWq-2UoOkCjCR-QHzWWg17-Q==> 


Contextual Context


On Marketing Land, Danny Sullivan says that in a new marketing campaign, Microsoft is trying to position its Outlook.com email offering as privacy-sensitive versus Google Gmail which allows for contextual ads cued by keywords in a user's email. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6srtk4Zl7P75pL55ADYPE75IePnlpdC7JwFa1d_Cd2SBR_o8_pKsZC1b21q11ZEbZHNFPrUdWY2FSojnbyGI3kQTJUwyerONYfPlw_ziMllGRgCDhVaDBkGoNIW0EChKIQ65VTxo3O7VVYKIZpAEVPWY4pRshB3Dtu_vwW9FBSXOqQ-bilD99ngQqV2ulQbbY68BMrfqWBeisw==> . Ironically, the same Google tech that provides contextual targeting in Gmail, is providing contextual targeting on Yahoo now <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6sqRba85RAGyNoKPdITeEfROxHhLoOYJk8sElxCHwOf0Fd-ZlhNXQDnChx0RdZoCkvDrVnbnSnkNwDN_BTw6cGLt3mxuSK9lsvPLPiZNV_l80y78BnCrX9CIB_xvphKI1u2b-c6I09KQH7hG5Jy83kg-ccI-UNBE4YL2BZ0Wul7JKw==> . Has the Microsoft world just gotten a wee bit smaller? The challenges around search monetization with Yahoo-Bing haven't helped. 


Creative Media Practice


On Digiday, Jack Marshall reports on the creative-agency-growing-a-media-practice phenomenon. He notes, "AKQA's media practice, for example, is now over 100 people strong, having doubled in size in the last two years. It might not be working with the global 100 media spenders, but smaller clients are increasingly looking for everything under one roof when it comes to digital, the agency says." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6sqy8tYdkQINTG-EaAtEMccV6hQi_fGe81fZr3_fWADu6mk84vVBUrOM1EYCst2uZH5JwFGo8p9TKEy_tXDb9AsneCkJzYkVTt8EyIXyL4zrzCaBHzagIEndGJq_Tf8YvRB9QfqpXdPpbG71a2duQV8H2N_nnoYFArUDfFLylm3r0g==> . 


More Context


CEO Ben Fischman of shopping site Rue La La told the throngs at Business Insider's Social Commerce conference that yes, Facebook ads work. BI's Laura Stampler quotes Fischman, "Display ads on Facebook ... has been effective (...) I think Facebook advertising, as long as it's contextually relevant, works." Big Data Winners And Losers


The shrinking cost -- if not the complexity -- of gathering "Big Data" can make it seem that all boats in the ad tech sea are rising as a result. But Simulmedia CEO Dave Morgan, writing in Mediapost, takes a closer look at the space and finds that the benefits are not being won across the board, even if the process of data managing and data mining has become more democratized. "I believe that the spoils will go to those who can move past basic data analysis and convert it into predictable business outcomes," Morgan says. "The future will reward those who can convert data into foresight and take bold, market-changing actions. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6sqCn7MuNv1tkBBJTb20bdg5xPu9OZk_3kEiVRzdQpqvsKG4qcJopBqWdT02O1Dal4f-Y0ByX1WhMSX4pRINLtDuep_U7g8eMBp8uUiA_OAX2ntsnTK-3ey5JIMtU-PfY2gli56WxBDmQWFIA8VuxsUNFBqWaUmz-LE2XSniqlrgWLvuBxlbAyfOrv9pV3ieI-exN4N0NYEEljFd7ZcfwGPzuOVjRGU3RyFU4i4m-DH1gg==> . 


Lost In Translation


Although emerging markets lag North America and Europe in terms of richness of audience data to be gathered and analyzed, brands that do take a chance on being first are likely to be rewarded, says Zedo social media director Francine Hardway, writing in iMediaConnection. While heaping praise on analytics provider Proximic for using "pattern proximity" and for ignoring semantic approaches. In other words, looking patterns of pageviews helps avoid the data from getting lost in translation, Hardway says that analyzing a full webpage can bring better results and reduce the chances of an embarrassment like the realization Chevy had when introducing its Nova to Spanish-speaking countries ("No va" means "no go."). Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ea4hEYZE6sokMmR4G-s4F71iPKQ6bczXnWb6tK8TQ6ZJsY9_teuf9Q7RuRzxNArTMUpri48bTRnooGWB5jpmpWF-uSsViGM-rCvhJPVrz2UUD6ZbflD4obAjFf1Uh7WCl-y8DytswyqMLFQDv35LpiOxMPXnKLN5jXwy0SAsR8qQdDg7Czh_v2Y0-TbIP4q69Di0Hmvw-3Lab8d_L8Wn3J_kIRG2Iu6Dhhgd0FrLkJ8=> .

'Context is everything to them, not a cost-per-action placement. They care about engagement metrics like completed view rates, as opposed to how something converts or if they can retarget'..." (visit AdExchanger)
*	Data Driven Thinking...Time Can Be An Expensive Programmatic Price Regulator by Andrew Casale, Casale Media <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwFIYXgIm-g1CHqaxSRqEuybIgS1FMAxYXsLSQLCj_0tkDizm7RuNfFukywlN8td6cWyVosqKTTSAuj22z4eWwEIX_g7KDPi04V4BAWRb7lCLQXzJV7huFsHSZRZLa4_2Lf-f562FOi_B84lOGCOVBfw2dDQlM4auBZTs7noqOUKe9DqoykyXvfox0tFBWw1JQyxfrGSyYerWRiSBx7_HcRW>  " It would appear that when any given hour flips, a good majority of bidders push a burst of bids through in the first minute to either catch up for under delivery in the hour prior, or 'get ahead' so to speak in the new hour, in an effort to help guarantee that they are pacing comfortably against their goals..." (visit AdExchanger)
*	Programmatic I/O Conference - April 8 (SF), September 16 (NYC) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwFQQ0tC_kaDeYEmbtrTaFKnj6ML8WuVPOOGyKiezqXift2M7tWiAGXNyYP-pgtUFwti8k-oXRIFV8IhOo7umJMCPh5dsc3mgpDv2YfKLKNYCw==>  (visit AdExchanger)

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwFlj8QZpF4zUojTI32wcdj84a1e7OsSDwQ0yUIy0EixLBMFwwKvHBHeP1kOvaGE9hKaoEEM-9KZrfkMwrb4szrKBiI5V94P-V4CQoBTT-XmNp5JPBzRKbMoK5d730qQK2s=> .

 

Floor Pricing Fixer Upper


On its blog, Yahoo!'s Right Media (RMX) announced enhanced floor pricing capabilities for "supply partners" seeking to sell display advertising through the Exchange. The use of "supply partners" instead of "publishers" is telling. Other than Yahoo!, it would seem ad networks use RMX on the supply-side versus any direct-to-publisher relationships. Perhaps, one of the only publisher relationships that exists is Aol which spilled some inventory <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwGHlexz8QGXCioAoaQvdcKT4aTL6bQ627LpfhshH581GdslcGLpFfOvwqV5NCxOVn7t51xlpUV2IbyHXk82aaxXN7WWLNjMoZaCzkiK8DRzFc7abZZ_ujy4_afqkOnqTMxm1JAfxWmVwTynRUMjscdKNomUn_tZzpWTtVaGj2vMO13X_pHUNKHkzRVJEuR3EwMQAacXXMmLEeE3wvr0nwNBqjDMNS7zgl4=>  into RMX as part of the nearly forgotten Aol-Yahoo-Microsoft "kumbaya <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwGN8uZpkJlyn-fycwq2XR5LlitKLjpxPkMzeUAO0nrUsoDzDjFYp-GbwNWTeQ5xc5X_tRPYxq31l_Rv4-a2GzsYbNWglONxh6hgqVlTBD4DpzUoSzn4f8dGkSMo8tYnlgbPgqNpYBbk0O8tKt0BGEFINlTCRWk6_c7pmdlhnBpVTn_jxeVFC9O_NCx4uo1jgm4J3wxKJ03_3UqffAMsL3pXOLF6tzBjv7u5CSS2sdFIroaRcwwa_FsMAhgBGlnjeiM=> " in 2011. Read RMX blog. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwFpb5-EeXJbL4wKkBSHzf3TnZgmRZMs9uP8vV16S82llc7eOlVso06hH14Q9H_wwq9EqSOSC12cYiSvtyPbgidWOD0cByxcX_2LaRN4PaLfIMYAMIKzzKZX>  Yahoo's inventory remains the sole, "tasty" inventory on Right Media for many demand-side buyers.


Tablets Aren't Mobile


The impact of Google's new Enhanced Campaigns rollout (blog post <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwEUXilbph20CUA7iuYwmZ6Fzcxagp6h3UdbvpAnoNJnSq8yHkQxuXv_MdHosB5pUkifp2WcUSbyCrfoaSG2FKPheVUktxHS0y9hs3yxPgUgaQ3q6vbN2VDCTsYfWizX6gUba-G8q54aJ2ln3_ad8NVlBYTxPL72fWarTEGqs5lMeA==> ) could be a big decline in granular campaign planning as mobile and desktop-based campaigns are squished together, agencies warned. In a position piece, Adobe's Bill Mungoven calls out how Google will henceforth lump tablet devices with PCs -- not with smartphones. "Google has made a clear state­ment to its adver­tis­ers: tablets aren't mobile. But they've taken it a step fur­ther and effec­tively said that tablets are desktops." More.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwER67wjgTQlOz18Y-ktmp_D4_7nI36ffRHDaETNIseeHt-7LRxOoXX4-OC8b-35gIOgs4MOS5OpM8xAzH8Ybqhtj6Oyo6DOQBPKbLmErM0aVUQMG7JEEAFlzKNny7a8I3mSX9ItznCZliJlPJui9kurcz7yVOEVmmUBpOiDKnsAcb49JibSVHQUWpfMyGjX1kJs0RKPPDhN-Br1LN0GDgrO80ksgefRv1Lta5-VQ5rbniMEWxglFBlDHwNCaUNHXo55wJ4fzpml_Q4v0yr0gbMOmS_WpLlrwDXXdWMIhZXs7w==> 


Take Me To Your Leader


The portrait drawn of AOL CEO Tim Armstrong by AdAge's Jason Del Rey is of a breathless corporate leader who is either the most hands-on, creative spirit or a maddening micro-manager. Still, Wall Street is impressed in spite of it all. "It's really easy to throw stones around the lack of traffic growth or the monetization around the ad inventory or the fact that Patch still isn't profitable," said Heath Terry, a Goldman Sachs analyst. "But if you had bet anyone out there when Tim took over that AOL would be where it is now, there wouldn't have been a lot of takers." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwF-qKzlWFROTwsFJm4BYnMhlCuvd5VNX9Z9wFVoX2DQvvoamFNwXXZ7xRtfCiOgZ7fL4LduQPB6y-cZWJgD4_M_L-7lgxaq67siujtNo67tYaPKIKSNuYaUJ55XQOF1UJPpdN0Kp2N6zi6Nbd_EP9bPBundwa22PaCp0CMCJ9WrZPNntJKys_xqDk2JG8MceCQ=> .


Programmatic's Promise


Now, now, don't be ashamed -- you're not sure if the term "programmatic" is synonymous with "real-time bidding." (Actually, you can be a little ashamed, since you should have read this piece defining programmatic <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwEMHUygXzpSLkCwPY1uZ9w-MsDGWAapj6QeIWP6EPsyPKwgfalpgnCEiGKA6luYWOKQ5WKtvaBgtutwRVzZocVJb5-8pS_UuHabzVzVmPvhv5Q-oICA4zqhnfnnT1SDBWIAQeT6MvAIGI480oLOhjjSyyan-7BGEE6mFcl13yXo3w==>  and this one on RTB <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwEUXp0zh56kjWq2YCdjGKGIMFLcgLdaQ2TIhE1LHWCrMMhd7Cx-MojwVZQUyFRQurMFqEEyuWZBIXmkbkojQkobkpzL0NOR34mgaISPvOWvGElhtzUkGC1TivoxrEjR_xfeQqR8jwf2KpuSevztqq-Y-PQ8iE3Nk60=> , but we'll let it pass this time.) In a Digiday post entitled Programmatic Isn't Just RTB, Walter Knapp, EVP at Federated Media, COO of its Lijit Networks unit, writes, that programmatic's advances are "far more powerful than simply targeting and buying audiences at scale" through RTB. The promise is in "restoring the balance between publishers and advertisers," he says. "We reclaim this balance by leveraging programmatic technology to understand the motivations of a reader and then place a message at an appropriate time and creatively in the right channel at a value attractive to both the marketer and the publisher." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwFKu5PHbl8z-dueXCNBzdVehLdEQBdZcEDuvp2uSygoBbadedegbEP4TfV0-ce75H8baX58RhGQsF7BkedIZy2Gw5RasfJ72QU3-LhxLXyzqvSZXwfWkmFF93R4hyWWJ2hzr3dFSaSbCk7Is2_l1dCIlfdghRAXXV8=> . 


Rubicon: No Sell-Out


With an IPO in mind, Rubicon Project CEO and founder Frank Addante tells Mediapost's Joe Mandese that the company's strong balance sheet means that no matter what happens, it's going to be more of an acquirer, not a takeover play. It's brought in some new hires, including Mediaplex Founder & CEO Greg Raifman in as president and founding Overture CFO Todd Tappin in as COO & CFO, and moved others out in attempt to further expand the company's demand-side services. "We never referred to ourselves as a supply side platform," he says, they don't want to be seen as a DSP either. "A DSP is there to service the advertiser and help them optimize their campaigns... Our strategy is to bring the buyer and the seller together." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwGvUbf0LV29sSs5FO2a-QumhYU_tdM1ohQbqDXPwnf91y9HLoM1Dav4axtOnpxzAt6QLfPkOAwqgbBo-zlBAlng_43cu8OqlqeFJ1IeaASlGNGEUCSY9ra3sKznvfdsbR-GuWZX24UCr7ufOdIMU1qqnx4YkLEeQplN55UJ4AyLoFUNECQ4OVhGJmkzb9aTEN1vbSNW1QXpJ_xYwf68WyspyqVJoyZogPkjbYmV-Hmfkh44UgMM94qu> .

Location, Location, Location


In the early days of mobile advertising, the notion that geo-location was the most likely way to drive revenue was all anyone could talk about. But then, the realization was that brand marketers don't want to wait for a person to approach a store's vicinity. So targeters looked for more PC-style, cookie-like approaches to connecting consumers with ads. Meanwhile, geo-targeting specialists like Verve Mobile are pushing back against that notion, suggesting that mobile campaigns leveraging location-based campaigns outperformed non-location ones by a factor of two times, reports Mobile Marketer's Chantal Tode. "The most surprising finding was how poorly exchange-based inventory performed - we knew much of the location data in exchanges was specious but didn't realize that the majority of it was inaccurate," said Verve CEO Tom MacIsaac. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwGnMSDm9cXqgfm72dJAwfcuMPSa0m56G2MX5_bpwWlA-Ma1Mtb9Zon8cf4dO1ZV2_6D9MvHRMGz6Bvp7i6Vm1XgCiKtoevc0RPk_oFxRNwNfHDPHEpyblUYM49d5_0jdFmeSuz8iCj627S4X16wgqf5KX1HxyKFO3Q=> . 


Big In Japan


AdTruth, which competes with BlueCava and Tapad among others, signed with Yahoo Japan on cross-device audience recognition. The companies say in a statement, "Just in the last two years, Yahoo! JAPAN's audience recognition challenge has grown exponentially and will continue to do so as new devices emerge." For all the noise about Device ID in recent years, the space feels quiet going into 2013. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwFgDyaomXIG21Swcp-g2VV030-Hsj3vIGNf9vEeHz-e-X0oaVAJzqVYu7byl7veTfl9OJqOJO2sgu3kh2813m2ePumUxIGecV8DCS-knSwSo4jeNTJNHAEmgbibR9J5g5GzBKoEfyFwck0HRar_xO1Uix_xEKLuUZzPuJQpojTE4kGfiTQy9zNIkGtiYdeEpIdvXRrPca5h_Q==> 


German Tech


European ad tech marches to the beat of a different drum, as Deutsche Telekom demonstrates by acquiring retargeter xplosion interactive for its media selling unit. ExchangeWire says, "This typically follows the trend of German Sales Houses investing and buying local advertising technology players. A number of large German Sales Houses own - or are heavily invested in - localised ad server, SSP and ad tech solutions." More.


Rankings


Hearts were aflutter yesterday in ad tech land as Forbes released its 100 fastest growing, private companies list and a selection of ad tech firms were highly ranked. See it now. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0015BAMRBl-LwHRG1xoY0YpMECvn1MZK1eha9-fHyUCL-dBrOfc-WKI0DtZ-v6JgAbfzYn_OZ2Jt_X3vqV0yiUat_5R-lqOwnc1geyCMZzd8hlS8oBlUo_UtT09wY-uq254245PF8JIQ1mRVA8Af4H0TD6eAkhOJcGu>  Rocket Fuel and OpenX finished in the top 10 while several other ad tech firms were listed in the top 100. Forbes discusses its ranking methodology thusly, "The final assessment is based on growth (both in sales and hiring), quality of management team and investors, margins, market size and key partnerships."

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?

Amazon Coinage


Amazon is adding a virtual currency with a gaming element. Yesterday the company announced Amazon Coins. From the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzNuKfBEaIvvoTj237GNs9M8Z0BFOqT9MZs8-Hx86vVxMpRVG457uG-lGxLmopgbWBEK_0HVFfP1P05WUDK2MGrSq_2IhyjGbfCIau8Pzj0sIdO49Eyeg41Z4OvfZiYYyerpB9Cwa5jX3002dSJ_YBpJRzccwPdWnlazi4e-TK2SRuUaO1VnnsBerEFPtOnClf7-Cr7BNxgDZLDkSRzhByHT> : "The new virtual currency for purchasing apps, games and in-app items on Kindle Fire. [It offers] app and game developers another substantial opportunity to drive traffic, downloads and increase monetization." GigaOm notes, "App developers will get their standard 70 percent revenue cut on content purchased with Amazon Coins." No need for ads? Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzObww64lGS3RKgOVclPUQykr_2MsOK5hsRDXW8BsEuLDznGWA-crMrsu7cTC8fzjct6Z2sLQfyq_sR31Tn1QSv9UyAgSbi_Ukw91cJhGu3sznET93p4H-Iwbh48SEoJK5UPZ-rWRbpkK0xxaqe1Fv1PQYoQ5hdebNFlvNKAyWATn1R3pKmOJ9qqiLqWdHibMOYVJ9lansnyYjn8vQQVAlu_>  They still gotta promote - and that's where the Amazon ad exchange/network comes in. 


Ad Block Whitelist


Browser plugin kingpin Adblock Plus has given Reddit its blessing for meeting its "Acceptable Ads guidelines." Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzPLlpY0452rCMY-6OEMs190TAd9apQVYn_FQZmw2ARPCZ6HscrbvXjdhDu1eoOiVSPW_y1nUwc4FZEOuBnzmUQYOwM2sUtl0QssmgaLR2TNkpQ9-pTQN3X0S5EmHkgNQMRB5FxXU8t8G2Fsb9uQ6WVq8IxO2ZZHoex9_9az-JX9wV9BNfp37ZPS4MZVtJkE2cY=>  The whitelist program -- enabled by default -- is a way for users to opt in to reward sites with non-obtrusive ads (static ads only, preferably text-only). "Only 25% of the Adblock Plus users seem to be strictly against any advertising," the company says in a FAQ. "They will disable this feature and that's fine. The other users replied that they would accept some kinds of advertising to help websites." More. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzNzVmxmeZagBCNQxfzOaZgZ5g2navY4BNsU7H_lCYpwu-6A-7rCWzD13MQgb0Xw3mfpbclzJITRyjFccdmhbf1AGCKg7lbYrGKgK54aNJhmLRcUnsJoN4mfr1CsvXfuGsU=> 


Boob Tube Profiles


AT&T researchers are testing ways to use channel surfing activity to create enhanced data profiles of TV viewers. MIT Technology Review explains: "The data-anonymized to remove identifying data such as names-included details of channel changes and volume adjustments plus some demographic information. By assuming that someone was watching a channel any time a TV stayed tuned to it for more than 20 seconds but less than one and a half hours, the researchers built up a record of which subscribers had watched what channels, and when." Tune it in.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzOANXITe-X12Cap39BR1M-MsEI1tlK6xGz-B7a3Ux4At8pbjZAuzg_xaVEyODMUElwoUwp7NcsaMmy-7VHDqV11ZXpcAG_mm96SlEHga7-jpigTP4b9_DX3jWBmsDemgXHxLQntLWmZFnkBGzuMAyxFnwOjIpLwzbRwn-9PzHMV5rG9Qhls1h5FjhKTKJyR5v-Ra_mkIejL0kKPFH7VntGv> 


More Guaranteed


Ad network Undertone makes another "money-back guaranteed" pitch with a new promotion tied to display ad viewability and using Moat and DoubleVerify tech. The company offers a "make good" to advertisers with the "impression guarantee" and says in a press release: <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzOE3svQXPfgIKVpzM34BfV7rQGj42_1XcEtZERBvyCt6NOTFB4gkpoz2wWbCvM5dU_DWIp6YBtX_aeFeYKRh8jZQ52v45VgdR26OVmYilFEqPp-3nXSiU9izuJoo6wOXB0I70y03UOigFoSxUxYWsja>  "Advertiser campaigns running across Undertone's Preferred Publisher Portfolio will beat an aggregated industry benchmark for display ad viewability. The working definition of a viewable impression from 3MS (Making Measurement Make Sense) is a display ad unit that is fifty percent in view for at least one second." In 2008 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzOGUEJ8jPm3rZ2IsjuROz3QTPPNpcg5sIo7Y6TlubjVwFgp3khcb4vL0bTskPauefVrrQpWurnxgCb99V6QgwnEoCoHoeldVzphnfHKK8LwbHPRIs4HTQj5N4dR3DJZJIFIbmdcWCJJpDlWbsWGldLHvPz07FbP44Gm4Kzd62Mng7PjB4tvbKbtAO24GmPNmuVQP4hT65K4kQ==> , Undertone employed the money-back guarantee for brand-lift- and then again with Nielsen's Vizu in early 2012 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzOsXc2_6eBNeeq4nLbFVq_nkmXrbKw-H3IbEjJJKDb4RNOS3Nn6N2d1RJ-P8Md49A4HscQl_IJ1QhHEVJHqBfoPyBd5THBKGHE-3CW_a8pD2z1BoC8n8KCbWDZeADy6v9df3NaRZdVle95joDaERLOovjl79lZnHL1bkyIM3xFv0CoQiqasKsPzkPpV5qRM1YjKwZI2_lRhOaqNc2VHj8Wy> . 


New Global Agency: DigitasLBi


Publicis Groupe, which bought <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzOLKoZ_jIKf6M1GP52WtgqyGgn3GcxWefkC83qvDNMda6QHSPo4ZhrklNLZH0teuANE6EB771Uc8vB6FqHogiy0q_VM775FnUDfANzxWxy8Fu6Ea4r4OQAKXxjrmKNB1MU-rT9kDF3v5ldx2wPoPYU3o9ipr4qooeXimgJdn2FgkmWsM2Tqk7EXDg7Y_uE5fzAqDT5vTXt4hbwvotTwNadzU8sj2Qr_k2I=>  LBi in September, will merge the Amsterdam-based agency with its US-based Digitas. LBi CEO Luke Taylor becomes global CEO of DigitasLBi, reporting to Publicis digital honcho Bob Lord. Lord said in astatement, "One of the key strategic tenets of the combined DigitasLBi offering is the scalable, flexible technology and product suite that will help meet the full spectrum of marketer needs from audience engagement, to sense- and-respond content development and publishing, to real-time relationship marketing." The combined agency has 5,700 employees and outposts in 25 countries. Press release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzNdRFAmFxkSGVigMCYHzbnme__MFOS-VOGx5ZLCL9wc-FxDnqfZDxNuIXqVtQrpOEVYTWLt3HwleRhsgLOQCvWVbXf8wxkd3S-mduAoInyAEclH3gq_mNfvcVYZjWIxTs2qG5KKBCdlfxOsWhSWxPO1pnpyU1YrVEyZ9GPdL6-Q7Sbb3-v2bqcOSuelWMqYFOHDff8ej-wpSxbAT6QfWWyBqFTzAPI3b98=> .

Your GRP Is Showing


Video ad technology company BrightRoll, owners of BrightRoll Exchange, have produced a new whitepaper to explain the state of the GRP (Gross Rating Point) online and off. The company also positions BrightRoll products for marketers looking to buy GRPs online including a "comprehensive iGRP calculator." Get the whitepaper (pay with some PII) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzON0gqy1qTHFoPaSIcof0x6Kxu-pIroarABX4VlXGrAZBC7lh-1SGWtnJ3FhMEX0JhfJ-sw3CGZnXYjQb3KIEBhODgrSQ0mvu5jXttYy2acGema2snUgQRv_iiwKmwkVCxcwwNjl25ZcKIGNjQqn-S9> . 


Diversify The Ecosystem


On iMedia Connection, Maxifier's COO Denise Collela says that more women are needed in male-dominated ad technology companies. She sees several ways this can change including: "Having more women in senior leadership roles will help address the lack of women in the industry for a number of reasons. First, they can become role models and mentors for other females as they overcome the obstacles traditionally associated with balancing home and work lives successfully." Read the others <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzOgn6WAD9Nan9CssckO4cEgclkPM0h739MOyuvkFRRa710ccky_Z0D3wRJQVHBGtV1UMS6vR2GkMsD5lT8rmb2jbxspJgoYtDaVGyN1lWaFgrhN11qp0VexyuWQgD3M23yNZNFLlSUuGw==> . On his Upstream Group blog, Doug Weaver tackles "People Like Us" and makes the case for diversity in the digital media workplace across race, gender, education and age. In regards to the gray hair crowd, Weaver writes, "Recently a close friend of mine - an amazingly talented career media seller - shared with me how several recruiters told her - directly - that her age would hurt her in getting her next job in the industry. The fact that a recruiter was willing to talk about this directly tells me the problem is pretty awful. Experience, wisdom and the long view are things we need more of, not less." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzPaDq0XxQRIXa4GhuOInUGM_ASFeFjD_NMmtDi05laTnuRgFybmTvv8HgDQE7K60naO4qb3z45jblnI94VYtBvB_4XQs5zJUd8hzed4eQxm40s-FhtRoTAK-nmrQvR79aM=> . 


Google Programmatic


On Thursday, Google will be ripping the lid off of its programmatic strategy until the end of time! OK, that's not how the GOOG put it, but the IAB's Steve Sullivan will be quizzing DoubleClick Ad Exchange product maven Scott Spencer about the programmatic future - and you can tune in.  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzNcSN8liHn_lApAB3IA0ry6Pjbz4cxKby4Dq4MgZVcdiKwJZAkII5g10ctnWzYfLv3H3rg0Z3DROCPGBGgPDhAiVXA25Se-LTZ48Z9T35WPsiVwI2Fzj8gRlkvUCkmHGdpyQCffwbAmS8efGdJY1_EroHv-Nb9NEE7SYbM9Qf4YekAks61bCBJcyW_p6qqP6Qp-5mgvSUU-1Q==> Read more on the DoubleClick For Advertisers blog.


Malware Flag


Netseer was flagged for malware by Google's Chrome browser on Monday. Danny Sullivan of Marketing Land has the story, "As it turns out, the main netseer.com domain was infected with malware, though subdomains used to distribute ads were not. Nevertheless, that subdomain got nabbed. As a post on the NetSeer home page currently says <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzM5oLG4N-OC1UyyXRnIN37DvwOxC5M1sRrIW2b21zLVvUL-gvMGQ9CyRcIamlgwZlQ-_0FMj_E8h4xfFmOQUpMkCyasqj7gLvlHO5wHdVf-WQ==> ..." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzPTAM9MPcRwUEd0Ej22kRxF_fTDh7dvkUy0pJ5taYwGGAfGUSdcckJAcecV3cmZWZyQLKfwT2giPaNRenFUHIOAYdnHLmKqIFA5XXZsUt3W7i-eU5yD-BlNR7UhPAT4ths8-WvNPgG-z4EYGnodclEsagww4cFCYsaCUhydK6687UfIRvLplEbgryTnroQiB0GXyqmE61WAmQ==>  Netseer responded and said the problem was quickly fixed. A post on Netseer's home page <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzM5oLG4N-OC1UyyXRnIN37DvwOxC5M1sRrIW2b21zLVvUL-gvMGQ9CyRcIamlgwZlQ-_0FMj_E8h4xfFmOQUpMkCyasqj7gLvlHO5wHdVf-WQ==>  added, "Our ad serving infrastructure is completely different from the corporate website but shares the same domain (netseer.com <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzO0RFCPP510muA4mhExzBRujK3jfr0xD7QCeRQ7MHoaDXRfJYvWli7l9DhqJ_lC23vkDe41G-7MgMcxXR0IUCZ1Xl7sEHweSU4=> ). So although the malware never impacted the ad serving all our ad serving partners saw Chrome and other browsers flagging malware warnings to users. To reiterate, the malware was never served into ad serving stream and the browser behavior was completely due to ad serving and the corporate website sharing the same domain name." 


Call In The Red Cross


What to do when natural disasters hit? Call in the Red Cross or, if you're in media, make available a phone number or link so viewers can make a Red Cross donation. Along those lines, the company which famously tracks hurricanes among other weather phenomena, The Weather Company, has added Red Cross chief Gail McGovern to its board of directors. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bo120_RUIzNxUswI5kggnkLXhPoiEb0vlSdo2sPXvn7184f34Zja2NZvw11mhW15mMhJpJAFsZm29SFejMdipRaBQX00_BCsKchwEAogt7bwHjhpP-lNLGa5ZJ5nxYJno5M3BHFYlZ1XI5H3IAoc1VA4JEsUGYX4RKu1G0Ycf-vOWaJ1tYhQQ7dHExNVqF1iG72ExAhQ6Qg9CJ212lm47BKBQ30uIoXkPDWZzd0tqwU=>  At the very least, this is a savvy public relations move by CEO David Kenny. His company benefits from disasters as viewing surges - like it or not. It's just the way it is.

As a buy side guy, I have to say that publishers often over think what is going on over here on our side of the fence. Its not that complicated in many circumstances. Often, we've simply found a more efficient way to conduct a direct buy, no paper work, no tags, no discrepancies, etc..." (visit AdExchanger)

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa0Q476ehuwEWJq6Hug2DEKl7AUrwtoWx4FCZk0E1ZKfgVkNolRjhJLAiJRjBEkf0b29xYDPEiCkRT_Bu71ZkW8UJTHh8GLL7rnmJoduOwYtasfvDmwKDbNfUWMc0YS3HT8=> .

 

Native Ads. Standard Disclosure.


Facebook has caught some flack from agencies for opting out of the industry-wide privacy compliance program. Well now it's yielding to their requests to accept the blue "AdChoices" icon on retargeting ads served through Facebook Exchange. But there's a key difference. According to the release, the icon appears on-mousover: "Upon request of a DSP (demand-side platform), Facebook has agreed to add the AdChoices Icon to the 'About this ad' link available through the drop down menu, which appears when a user clicks on the grey 'x.' In addition, Facebook will replace the current hover text message, 'Report this ad,' with a more explanatory phrase, such as 'Learn about Facebook Ads.'" Read the release on the Better Business Bureau's site <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa2U3i8QH9a_xHNZCP3mcewINR7xwCWTuVOEJslVYgz-wcWfLgeiQ_DvS4q76s8kNbY3bwPzeE8sI7tvpbdRC11d8IypVDYh9Aru4Y57v-soLmX0AurQQoY2cNI5Jv7tALR-U5neheOcjBM_NAgWI9yUBq0oksnXk9iZ8MjMxRpr-Pe7FK93JFDHOW-VyrUKxMNJ0Kw8i3PASz-ntIv6ZU4XC53ubrtQ73c=>  - someone loves acronyms. 


Teeing Up Guaranteed


PubMatic takes another step toward "programmatic reserved" with new deal management features for its private exchange product. CEO Rajeev Goel tells AdExchanger that over 10% of PubMatic bids are $10 and higher, creating incentives for sellers to let RTB demand sources compete with potentially less lucrative direct sold campaigns. But it also wants to support negotiated transactions. "We need to deliver with [clients] the opportunity to manage their business on a holistic basis." PubMatic into more direct competition with AppNexus, which is preparing its own plans around guaranteed. Press release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa04-KECttkmf6EJFg1Ld0-Wvixr3V5BawfG6NF8LU7C3s3kI8BA0ihoUPA4eI4N_evREs0rJ9VC-23RxVl18ojG1G-wBGbBo-Gxt4xFaHC3Hlx6VXYVArrBwGwU_93VuchdOF8zkOaEcy7gT4CNZwPMZbweVwj7THYKW0l71OPZeKW3m7soBMzNQB0kLcY52GzIPYGSE2t5WvN9B814omcmlY-u2GQburKK8T4TXmJR2A==>  Watch for the full Q&A later this week. 


Yahoo: No Joke


After a well-received Q4 earnings <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa13iolHdDIXFseRMQCxfoxU7Wa0_9Z0nBMuq2SXwTisbK8qEMIZNgk9DKMVwbkAUicSkE3ttBCxy46ZGWzMORKg_lNkzo5sd2AlhuvJmAwS7NUKv64LtAZED5tjZFfTPoa66qKE_0EsEx21HGH0aEVPSujRLwADZJMw_hAWrdmpJZ07AdLXn0nMVpfYuEBJn66MZMiGeiMz_puzkJwzeW8gKr7ASXNPNV4=>  report -- thanks in part, to lower expectations from analysts and investors -- Yahoo appears to be on the right track these days. In a Marketwatch opinion piece, Jon D. Markman, an investment adviser, says that the Microsoft Bing search partnership which resulted in higher revenues and less cost for Yahoo is having the effect of "freeing up resources to further grow its display advertising segment," which represents 42% of its total revenue. "There may still be some near term hurdles to overcome, but for the first time in a long time, Yahoo is on the right path," Markman says. "It finally deserves its exclamation point again." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa3RMR56aGBmfYH-KCI_wrDxfrLJUJBvje2yOHRuLKOaaBSo0-kBBbjrNE9rjIZHKw0P5wE8W4MOqu1qiuwhNBvOrTRpcMJIEQ7lw7a_OLgcysZtArA-_KhKYfvfB9Ule-NeWy3LzQlH6qiOrxyIY-6BTVW0krc0tlUx_OSvXzpy8g==> . 


Gannett's Digital Revs Rise


Gannett is still mostly known as newspaper and broadcast company. But digital is starting to contribute a significant portion of its total revenues. Its digital-only revenues -- which includes the rich media provider PointRoll -- were up a mere 3%, but company-wide, interactive dollars jumped 27% in Q4. Read the earnings release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa2fXdc97L9quDHqF9xH09vFUXYPiVBDjpMP-ChEakQz1aBuTigCnWPybAfZzHPW1tku3MA9K67Gzv2RSrtgrXty9Kab-pQINx2FCKWy3UsOqq4G3CiEKOyPEy837PqQwOyj89n9illwnmCCwIc3tSgpOSy0mJa4HtpaTHmFt3upfA==> . Meanwhile, Gannett completed the rollout of metered paywalls across its U.S. Community Publishing unit and said the initiative will reach its target of contributing $100 million to operating income in 2013, said Bob Dickey, the unit's president, News & Tech's Chuck Moozakis reported. As CEO Gracia Martore told analysts, "Extending this reach for new digital-only subscribers will continue to be a focus in 2013 as we accelerate our marketing efforts to drive growth in the digital-only customer base to 5x to 7x current levels by the end of this year." Read the Seeking Alpha transcript <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa2OpZ17quyB7uKHx26ZQu9g7wrR9YE7DN-sNZ1O9VmTHPn4TsRRKpiWZpAaV57mKWieDEg9kpdFC_j9irjJpX3A3FlhinV8dRyCV-VFf0CPKS5yhuMyZvHLUHVJ3MB1pVidNXzJj7ZnQzxvLABFiPP0K1fzI6tTmwN27HyRkdBtcbm15M8t4o9lxy4iSzx5EFBDfwV8bz1Yxao9ofT-SOxe-5U11HwlI8HPGSdjdBVaPMF6VPEEVP8k> . (reg. req.) 


Agency Trading What?


Only 77% of ad agency executives claim to be very or somewhat familiar with agency trading desks, according to Advertiser Perceptions Inc., which surveyed 345 ad execs. While that's a pretty solid majority, it does suggest that there is a significant pocket of agency professionals who aren't aware of how media buying is changing. For example, just 64% of respondents say they were very or somewhat familiar with supply side platforms. Among agency executives, awareness of SSPs fell to 58%, ironically trailing the awareness of marketers (63%) by five points. "There's so much noise in the ad tech marketplace that its creating a lot of confusion," Randy Cohen, a partner at API, tells Mediapost's Joe Mandese. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa2GP6RJdw5oggwflip-5vwQ8YRm6YwjqD6JXrG6hULYDQEj44r_O4XREyb3v46tRr8uT1VpYvuigpEJuN-krkrxaCxKz-7-Cwcx0LUTYb74u85V3tailAOfA2llJQRsB_B6v3zqLzNIy90AffYujeui1_RMDrM_IZb4ruGoMHEeMqjWGoQzVEHafx86B7wamRKS7RLVZB-_i9tDMwZ7GY5r36I3XfcrMDhrQ6W0Rx3DhXSySjyAeErg> .

How Long Viewability?


Havas Media ad ops guru Chris Swarbrick tackles the ever-popular topic of viewability on AdMonsters. He discusses the nuances, "Even the definition of a viewed ad is debatable. The IAB set it as at least 50% of the ad seen for 1 second or more but their own display advertising guidelines also allow up to 15 seconds maximum run time - so, for many, one second may be far too low a threshold." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa08oi6lldh20qN-6btWTilj23xEiav9waRWrfi3d4q60fm__vpkcwf_GWCYTTFjf2WzzpDzID4_CMOv1KlqL8quXs6T8a0aRAex2EBCGF7_D4p8YkIVTBkiRkKHB5HtgGLEIn5I94S4a1zgGW6KCpuzFq7XXZGAuqRNuURSBt6Apg==> 


The Lotus Position


How long until U.S. talk show host David Letterman has a top 10 on programmatic buying? Not soon enough for buying platform Rocket Fuel as they've created created answers to a series of questions marketers might raise when considering buying programmatically - such as "Which channels support programmatic buying?" Download the whitepaper (pay with some PII) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0011AkjWNwHEa35oK5xzUPf_jSHnNOd1GGp5wLjfoka1vsfj3wS0lPfdneXNFPY1uTQ4ShPvua77wx2_PN5PFUWLq8K_Ouy-VVd3iHpNbA8amsfDCg643AGbIyPoQDrAv9e1zretw5LQJNIfzvwhntcCtZkVuQZ13rek0APF3ZbTlnplKz6B2XOX5OmfQPoWpsM1cas7BpMaDbt-se-y6ClISK4ECScpUkB>  - includes photo of CEO George John in the lotus position.

FTC Privacy: There's An App For That


As Jon Leibowitz prepares to step down <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQEH2gxIZ7kEzI-NuZfTT3PDrAd4IogUJjjjeZsDcFri3c09j-qIZyRJYDtWuaW5YOJKzP7yNTE4Wv6oSMXq7V-oDQ2gEcBt54zFYgCnmZGsKPrGoiT4XA4jKw8NCQBlBRdcrszfMiXQ48wYQj_Vfldpl0IE7jmpFsz-WiXkh2e45oE0ugClHNBl9W0wt89F3sMT0-4G6VsQ6iRdGiPjmOW5mZFmGalqP3I=>  as the Federal Trade Commission Chairman at the end of the month, he's leaving a departing shot directed toward the companies who run smartphones' operating systems and mobile app developers: insert a "Do Not Track" function and other consumer privacy safeguards into your products. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQHB5gspHYSfc8LN6yIMsQ4AQUZsLfHGYOC057X-ygKVgI_tTZyV0euQ6EKeov127gjT01fVXGp9VzG0hsHm4aWSkQW5wfaxQvmMVfwaL5KLPDvZE6ds7z_EHQ6FTIkIW3uc2QAisUp8ctFbjAEQR1qy> . According to the FTC staff report on mobile app privacy issues, 57 percent of all app users have either uninstalled an app over concerns about having to share their personal information, or declined to install an app in the first place for similar reasons. "These best practices will help to safeguard consumer privacy and build trust in the mobile marketplace, ensuring that the market can continue to thrive," Leibowitz says. 


Twitter Hack Attack


Just as Twitter continues to try to find solid footing for building its ad business <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQEGJVdPrsNRxHvTaxnqM4jzIR6v767bMIgsDdl8Q6qf4Y_O0JFG44WyOUKBweIyStHtkYJ2cKIPOUGwb3yDIZv6RF6SnTc98jBmqP11YbUtj_s7fkh105_VRrLwXsZAyvHitm9nFi32rrbiopKQ9VMPRNEcMl3Ro6Cd9V97j9tIwbaI08z_tUYBQFpqsSABGpLdLIiJKUpOJAevGwI8lplg> , the microblog became the latest high-profile media hacking victim last week. According to a Twitter blog post late on Friday, attackers may have had access to limited user information - usernames, email addresses, session tokens and encrypted/salted versions of passwords - for approximately 250,000 users. Read it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQHpjsmy4UGpm2DwAqr13xgAIHv5wQTx6G-KbyNtRX1KaHNgCTWtwGCtYc7DRkJjf_e3gAfhnmGcZJX-1MMZ3wiPPzLKdoRXv1G088LEfp7DASQgEO3cQW4bCco5cfHorIx342ftAgX-tcj9fLH_ChyMtAukMvCKzls=> . "This attack was not the work of amateurs, and we do not believe it was an isolated incident," the NYT's Nicole Perlroth quotes Bob Lord, Twitter's director of information security, as saying. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQFpiG3f1sZK8lt6hGeBWTeWZ775-jJj7UUydPC712pb_T3I7BPzHwrX-AG6X-kBwnaJN5Jt_BI_Mkbs95A8Bcq3xG7M2LDYg61KvNiV1L2ubCsWQbZ5B9obdEJtAP9uFoOZ-oTk2RWGCGswwnrE5KN66zPU6baT8L0Pd0sabOB8DaVVi-1OvUKDAPUd8a0AieA=> .

Facebook's Last Click


The filing of Facebook's year-end, 10K financial filing late last week has yielded new findings according to analysts. Pivotal's Brian Wieser says notable 10k data includes: "Facebook has been successfully diversifying the company's base of developers away from Zynga, improving the value of the Platform to all of its constituents. For example, we estimate that non-Zynga payments remitted to developers tripled year-over-year in 2012, from around $300mm to $1bn. As well, the number of users who purchased virtual goods nearly doubled year-over-year." Read the 10K on the SEC's site <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQFu-8b5QYrZYuiL5ornUffX4oUW5heXI27AyH_kEVDZOSCp8ZnjmSuxlCSuG7ZX1L3RjFPZ54NQtJNMVlF0UeJN5TOBQKD2ICui0MgcPzakTL9oETJzaavsTyxOAQpJnFz2AkcZ45A2Ryf4aTbMiQZ0B9Thiqz_Bmu5eaEmtqgqmEkv9KB7qMckMjG8xfej1Ohy5CCc6MlcTw==> . Another part of the 10K is Facebook's focus on the importance of "last click". From the filing: "We use an advanced click prediction system that weighs many real-time updated features using automated learning techniques. Our technology incorporates the estimated click-through rate with both the marketer's bid and a user relevancy signal to select the optimal ads to show." Do views matter on Facebook? Or is the upper-funnel and building brand awareness about clicks? More 10k highlights from Inside Facebook <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQEy6VZ_cSrlZJfEc68JjLx6UTuBgv-jjkoxTmqDCQjUmWug_pQWNUIKAkRPPrxTDyrzESKrXktI1XSaXfguEEMwllpsCYQiKTNxjCmgDzIjJncxiKwJMxSDBpIv5mk22txOEOT__IdYH_j2b5CwUndjrUKz__602k3_iquxCPlgO8r0yCMdEslE4vO10f-1Lgd1tI9KISgcemR99CfGF5Iidc3M-QvAb0g=> .


Audi's Choice


When it comes to online media, you can do a lot with $4 million, notes Mashable's Lauren Indvik. For example, a big time auto maker like Audi "could have used to take over the front page of Yahoo for a week, to generate 100 million impressions on Hulu or to purchase any number of other high-profile digital ad placements." But instead, it went with a Super Bowl ad and Indvik wanted to know why. Loren Angelo, GM of Marketing for Audi, tells her, "We've achieved record levels of awareness and showroom traffic with national consideration numbers showing significant spikes post game." Besides, its "Prom <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQH06TU1k6AgZl6oaSBEBEMzPiddgt__2qkwrIVeSPrz13jD26bK_GIXJUapMd5ocmMCzHWLTs429t8wJ8ivse-M_y3TwkeS_gtLOyG5QcQEoNUc0BxfqMqBZI66EF3ysB31YS1E32Gt2cgfg5Las4BYf6CldaJoQXoyr3RJXss7FA==> " spot racked up more than 4.2 million views since its Jan. 24 debut on YouTube -- for free. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQGow2yURvldayr56RQe-gLHU1DfwXc79qBPE6Cm9wUYOJIG6sclaheymLkeSjlb7FUE3pKIy4PIg00bsDJDfbtr8JV_oNTYBhUwa44tWcflrmhiVuhOOAo_mihQmzwPLp7_tPir4J8bKwggL0I7i8zhJkAH703iQ6B5cMM9IuB2DNVPgL2f-9sIyYWWHg4BNXV4x3pL0D6cZ0y2yxlmoA52fuyvFb98nVbTnZbAO0AhEpDFS1snBLe3hSK4PZ4Z2Laq1p8dLhNW8fwVvNMcKgRTbA_OfmKH-50=> . 


More Agency Streamlining


Interpublic Group has merged the media operations at Draftfcb into Mediabrands, which is increasingly the center of gravity for IPG's media activities. The move follows a decision by rival holding company Havas to consolidate its Media Contacts and MPG agency brands into a new media unit called Havas Media. IPG CEO Michael Roth said in a memo the move "will allow the insights and expertise that IPG Mediabrands and Draftfcb bring to clients to be combined into an even more integrated set of offerings and capabilities." Are big ad buyers laying the groundwork for automation? AdAge <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQGGuaxzknvrqpCNw9KRruhAkaqC24SxIRfsd6k6rwzFvp2OWZaA9A06UlPGkzrLIgFR0QHekl9pSA1vHqy0I9DamcnaoLtZO6SH5PemMasx_RuIUmTgYvGiWwytSYXH-Yf03vO915jtQk12FUxOsYF8ZvVM5F2bLvcife6csYZvtS_71I0bBl3AG9gCpv3GbFeQrmAONZconQ==> , Mediapost <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQENFPTqx5-uzeIOLeHKFvMcagjwecn5AI-x9QoRFAsfxZfoianex4PUczd8CnNXDJKETFa5jt0lP7fBnnxh5SMFSJAfX6OLjyq36_pYbWd1-33SNibPTGu0g1vLz_VoZApcG8RMkGN9UBT4seH-KKgiDTlYDJUXEfjPSBsbO--K3mnL0qAHQsiJjiPpqvvC1uj1gx5-PWnoHURtuzb6EVQyh8ne7nM0qQK-EXR3az612usCXCVc75Aw> .

A Flurry Of "Crashlytics"


As mobile app makers juggle 30 to 40 ad networks and marketing channels, the likelihood of users experience "crashing" of their apps is also growing. In a bid to help app developers better understand which ones perform the best, mobile analytics provider Flurry is rolling out a tool designed to address that problem. "The company's crash analytics lets developers get automatic alerts on new errors and common crashes," writes Techcrunch's Kim-Mai Cutler. "They can then diagnose where these errors are originating from with full stack traces including symbolication." Read the rest <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQFhFt-BGOcWWZEoijaheK3QvgKYvZ7P24uYKSyLP2K1fFOtKQAz2h2RF60iAhI4B8OXORq9QBpnpZnsAnGybHFjfFTWyliwp85yTlh9Yo8Bl2ffOWQJcshu_wAUzF9T-z20vwEmPIxJBns1m-JkJOtE8oQzW59s4W4FpP1luC9ZD7EQNo0g-67Oi_3txmXiu0b6Ys7NELQ2IpoeUKqSpp9m_xXNsjBi6X5E6JcfU46_Y_jNpgKxsKgCgeE9qD7P0Lz397w_tjCc0XWX9hFA69pJbCDpqKAO8lljjJL1ZP0uZX7oUlWfYj51I8fnRTolRRHYewSsKtO4RQ==> . 


Google's French Newspaper Detente


Google will pay $82 million to settle a dispute with French newspaper and magazine publishers over whether the search giant should pay them to link to their stories, the WSJ's Sam Schechner and Inti Landauro reported. The settlement money will be deposited into a dedicated fund aimed at helping French news media navigate the transition to the internet, as print ad budgets dry up. In return, Google gets the links. "We made history in a very good way for the citizens of France," Google CEO Eric Schmidt said. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQH6ru3kGjQWX9vjaiQVK96R_pV4SJLJynjYET-6zvLcHX-AXNSgsIj7ofesLfKzHIzpSOQJvML0528YMbzMR7XP8RUsj7DHnXZmd5ATMQsKFY9t3wZH4wjyigcaGv6lkRu59xAmJRxGXgHvx9xKODdh19GnQCtP6TMwJDah8tKRZbf54n6L3bin> . 


Ad Safety Swirl


On AdMonsters, Shawna Stine from the ad operations group at "premium" publisher ESPN provides an anecdote that seems to show the client side is concerned about the brand safety of her site's inventory by requiring an ad blocking tag. Ad ops guru Ben Kneen chimes in, "Ad blocking tags are really a silly proposition for a direct-to-publisher buy on a branded publisher in my opinion. What is the buyer really worried about? It's not as though ESPN is going to start dropping racial epithets, write diatribes against a specific brand, or host pornographic images." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001fv-y9KHuxQGrrjp5h10VovVbD4zgxc1o6AhFQVJiGDLD5mGWsO-jogu2-mp8_SUiCljjv3MXvVxySVPEz0j5v3UpCoEMmHa8cRIJxBsLMjKFSyVbAcGQcZ8rhBX3bU4Gs60Ws4KO7LY1RP9PGDmaFaWkF1dFq5pQpkRFvICN0hNao69VKgEbVNdwowvHcDpN8HeeAq3qUip8ari0EGecXg==>

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>  

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K0pUuKGpMj9qHjcfXBnBfW0ZQ0ZbnyYi9MbT6E4lRP-vtUx-jujHWZP5hT-27VpiQbRCk-SW7uuEnmI4mzDDfXSYPRpDXr32Aoh0-eUVBkq3YMr2f1U9sfgYAx1gtEkzLQ=> .

 

Facebook Users Get Carded


Aside from building up search and ad targeting, Facebook is also deeply focused on e-commerce. The social network introduced its Gifts shop in time for the holiday season and to keep the momentum going, it's rolling out Facebook Cards in the U.S. users. "[Facebook] could even theoretically track which ads influenced purchased, where and when they ran, what else they might have purchased, and what offline stores they visited," observes Adweek's Tim Peterson. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K33e14vRv0sVVR-GuaC6R-puKmCl3ADrTmF70kAfPQbwip_uSmxibgPA6qKuoQVBtaiHaOdAlehH4nKMHHfULTyIXb6jPyNQXdqYqlDt8WtlU1OE5tDaQ5qGCbgQtX0fD9e701GIT-CyxQvr8Tq8gzNYZ1rt6tGdyzAsB8ZhnFLh_4hc8k5TLJYuOL2feo_IGbj1kR1XDd-oA==> .

'Big Data' Acqui-hire


Media intelligence platform/data management platform Aggregate Knowledge (AK) announced the acquisition of 7-person firm Quantivo <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K13XdALTSEQ1YEF6c1hrxyTxHRt_-Ze0ZelmS6lndjZrAGAHB5GyJ8FFm9UGXY_4qa91-iveo_qP5v7W536soRq1TG_WltGNa1Si-EzZAOo1Q==>  as AK looks to an "acqui-hire" to grow. From the release, "The addition of Quantivo's data science and engineering team will enable accelerated platform innovation ..." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K0vtm7p6_QRe39FyHjtF8drCE0B-nLn4sz3Jb8RFhsdxg3OLU_EejGZGPlDPNO0CQWQXEgXyDBIetG8yuZfrfkc_LYP1pzzjFikpytsrc9g8Xbrmej9D_ezFUt_eM1zRSquZVFnEW0uCUQF964h-bOkDL0z210izMcjTeDdTL9bWd7T6FGntjZmecS7w2kf3ZXEQ2kzQ4KZrNdkx4ynsCIY>  Quantivo had positioned itself as "big data analytics for everyone."

Get Me Influencers


Among the audience attributes advertisers will pay a premium for are reach, affluence, outcomes, and influence, writes GroupM Chief Digital Officer Rob Norman in a piece on MediaBizBloggers. Regarding the latter, Norman says that 10 years ago, "no mechanism existed...that allowed us to buy JUST the influencers." Now, he says, we can, by bringing "Klout-like" data with online inventory and other methods. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K0EcCs8xf3n0INq7peMQcgtXiLaLO0NRl_D69-SsOkP-eoD3inRHYfJ7PBb4-Cw-L8GOt_7kIcda4U_hpNWc3KlTlYkPyo6xBeBfq9MbJOKK1kA3wczqd59ZZ5mU7NDfNfEXTvXPvd3o_To_gR7nMO6X3-WuJsbtPFu0IZ4-Vh0KVNspT79WT0gpTbLrVcPI1TNEOQ-z7WkXA==> 


Audi Wins Super Bowl... And Loses


Experian runs the numbers on which advertisers stand to gain the most from their $4 million Super Bowl spots, and decides... it depends. If purchase motivation is the goal, Audi wins. According to its methodology, "There is a hypothetical 67% lift in likelihood to purchase the brand when targeting the Super Bowl audience." But the ad value shifts if you look at the $4 million price tag relative to the number of potential buyers. In that framework, Audi falls to near the bottom. Read the blog post. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K3BtpPFIZZSHu4NSEqHvHqFEqCTjstzhHGy5zrpMHcHRZLOutWlnxXTYS3RkngDpJWha7rLnWnbFUwi8LWGShCi0J2EwOIRnnDZN8LoZVlIn4v2iY2in8fa8DQcY67cS8ZbLwBtcpCzMm3djhvmiSGdxxZlGbWxUFFHR8HSW0kk9wlkc4L516uwnZXnSuqjoWmvm3zH_jlKgHJKY9_operbBajiQvaIeBUVpJtQvn9yqe3UYrTaVq3HOS7aqUInm6x5ddL8JubP6FLponn4QAcB> 

Cross-Measuring


As Wall Street earnings roll in, Pivotal Research analyst Brian Wieser reviews media conglomerate Viacom's outlook and sees a rosy future after it reported fiscal Q1 results. He paraphrases from the earnings call with Viacom execs, "Management expects that emerging cross-platform measurement standards will eventually lead to monetization of multi-platform viewing that will disproportionately benefit Viacom." Read about Viacom in the NY Post <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K3MlkfspOS-89H9op1yVyHfanzUDwN08onMo8l8Z4DKI0oujNN1hcF7k5Sk23EB5miBCI60hPz9aaJnjgemWLm3zMv251RZWaGRlv6QS2iPzd52XC2zRtHQTCvIJOv1V7mdYtAH5Iu9WTIZoS7uywd2z9AfmVQUYUGYfITM11NrGQ==> .

Viewability Future


Integral Ad Science's (was AdSafe Media) David Hahn takes a turn at the subject of viewability in an iMedia Connection post. Given his company's past history around ad verification, the viewpoint is well-honed as he concudes: "The future of viewability is in the industry's move towards programmatic buying -- in other words, using viewability as a predictive metric to target and optimize the media that marketers bid on in an RTB setting." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K24ZXGy3agd7i15Vc1Xb737Hm5EZ7LfNqtK2FMWqW0kJHgyjDJSqcxN7vehCiXzfZN6gx1JAE9MNWh382vvI9uxavdee1gWd7vYQIA5vrhli6P_boVABmJXaMclHOX_RTSHAB4NA8pRJg==> . 


Disrupting Video


Considering the many players in the video ad technology and services space, it's interesting to see Google roll-out is low-end, free video ad serving <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K33-GeAw0cl9LkqAO9fIeUme8-_ZLx95PZ30VHr92CjR64panvzceCkYGBYL008tFrbbdSj6v0GKS6ftd7_pJMpeD2fTC1VvgyuIr2WqEKoNY5TygUbsWtYC9G1todOGfFklp7o4-997wLlToJlGJRcmU_VA_Avi1yzHOMl3DEJYnYbqxbkOxOt>  in an effort to disrupt the market. And now, there's enhanced video reporting through Google AdWords for Video. See it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K0hvapdRseRB4KHuq7n8pNit08O6Hmf0N07rCs-UsNUE4ABiwtXrOdGxLK1ZXCy3s6XBkxZ6aNzZFXjwz1S0nk2B_bEMM9rjAKVjIZc7ogI87zZT5_3UXOCWFJWrJPDC-dC3LREvEyrD-Q86WytX6yp8IO_3KNSXm0PG5JF9625BMpG5IojcG0P>  It all sounds so easy according to YouTube product manager David Tattersall in a Google Inside AdWords blog post: "Want to build brand awareness? Select the Branding objective in the 'Columns' drop down to see how broadly your video ad was viewed. We'll automatically show unique viewers, average view frequency and average impression frequency." 


Microsoft In Graph Search


Gannett owned BlinQ Media CEO Dave Williams returns to the Ad Age pulpit and addresses the Facebook Graph Search topic. He notes Microsoft's involvement: "I had originally forecast that Facebook could develop a deep ad-targeting program by incorporating Microsoft search data into its ad-targeting tools. The integration is deeper than I'd thought: Facebook and Microsoft collaborated on a new search tool, enabling Facebook to use its own data to sell search ads, and Microsoft (which invested in Facebook six years ago) to enrich its search data with access to Facebook's social data.." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001rf6XDG9k8K2OA3SoPT_yzyMmf4IvtY9yDguCpoh9yklJCm9wN35BbQT6McGF7tqny2FPL7DNwoglVY3buGdNiDrhIowrI9QhDuYYIjYTxqhfcJcyVhGrSksqPhPbaIUuWSGymU4a7IPk83-1SD2KNLbilfRs_uGFA01sdag2NRK5at_psADY6S-txfHDqPaYS6O_-4S7349YzMLmvAdcvw==>  Microsoft's obsession with search continues. Will they ever beat the GOOG?
